Bike
: il telaio K1 (o K1 Disk / K1 Chassis) di Parkpre ‚Äî √® un modello endurance da strada, carbone monoscocca, con geometrie orientate al comfort, ma anche progettato per performance degne.
Comfort su lunghe distanze: la scelta di geometrie rilassate e materiali UD con foderi posteriori sottili permette di limitare la fatica su uscite lunghe, strade rotte, vibrazioni.
Ottimo se fai giri di molti km o usi misti asfalto/strade ‚Äúsecondarie‚Äù.
Rigidit√† sufficiente: non √® telaio ‚Äúda cronometro‚Äù, ma la costruzione monoscocca e la struttura permettono comunque buona risposta e trasmissione della potenza.
Peso competitivo: sotto il chilogrammo (‚âà 950‚Äâg) √® un buon valore per un telaio endurance disk con caratteristiche moderne.
Personalizzazione e design: Parkpre offre opzioni di finitura, colori, scelta di gruppi, montaggi.
Key items of kit
: la linea Adventure di Givi-Bike √® una gamma dedicata al bikepacking e agli appassionati di mountain bike / gravel che vogliono viaggiare leggeri ma con attrezzatura tecnica affidabile.
√à parte della collezione GIVI Bike ed √® stata lanciata nel 2022.
√à pensata per mountain bike e gravel, per chi ama l‚Äôavventura su terreni misti, lunghe escursioni, tour multi-giorno,
Include borse tecniche (da manubrio, da sella, da telaio etc.), tutte impermeabili, termo-saldate.
Materiale principale: Nylon Ripstop ad alta tenacit√†, laminato in PU (o rivestito PU) per garantire resistenza e protezione dagli agenti esterni.
Impermeabilit√†: le borse sono progettate per essere impermeabili, con cuciture termosaldate, materiali resistenti e chiusure tipo roll-top.
Visibilit√†: loghi riflettenti su varie parti utili per la sicurezza in condizioni di scarsa luce.
Cicloturismo
Sistema di fissaggio: cinture, attacchi specifici; la borsa da forcella ‚ÄúCarrier‚Äù ha un sistema ‚ÄúContatto / Fork Fitting System‚Äù per montar-e-smontare facilmente.
Leggerezza / compattezza: vista la destinazione (bikepacking leggero), si cerca di mantenere il peso contenuto pur garantendo robustezza. Inoltre ci sono elementi come i distanziali in schiuma per stabilizzare il carico.
Ottimo compromesso tra peso e durabilit√† ‚Äî i materiali resistono bene all‚Äôusura tipica del fuoristrada.
Buona impermeabilit√†: utile in condizioni reali, pioggia, umidit√†.

copertone Vittoria RideArmor 700√ó28C

Versatilit√† / utilizzo tutto l‚Äôanno

Compatibilit√† tubeless / Hookless
La versione a partire da 28 mm √® compatibile con cerchi hookless / TSS (un vantaggio se vuoi montarlo senza camera d‚Äôaria, con sigillante, per ridurre il rischio di forature e miglior comfort grazie a pressioni pi√π basse).
Buon grip / mescola
La mescola Grafene + Silice dovrebbe offrire un buon compromesso tra aderenza, soprattutto su bagnato, resistenza all‚Äôusura e anche un rotolamento non esageratamente penalizzante per quello che offre. Non √® un ‚Äúsuperlight‚Äù ma √® bilanciato.

About Us
Bikes of the Tour de Farce 2025
7 October, 2025
Our rider registration looks a little different to other events. Riders, on arrival, are handed a Top Trumps card, a raw egg, and a selection of paints and pens. They can then spend the evening getting to know each other and chatting through their questions.
We ask riders to self-police and score themselves on their 'privilege' which ranges, as you can see below, from the length of their femur, the sporting prowess of their family, the age of their kit, any sponsorship, and the amount of free time.
At the end of their event, this Top Trumps card will act as a form of taxation system which will adjust the final results. It's all very scientific. Stay tuned to find out.

It‚Äôs an aluminum frame with a carbon fork, Mavic Ellipse wheels, aluminum bullhorn handlebars, and a Campagnolo Ultra-Torque crankset ‚Äî reliable and easy to fix. I‚Äôm running MTB brake levers and a Vader saddle (basically an OEM Selle Italia copy, as far as I can tell).
Key items of kit
: It's more or less the same as I had for last few years - "dingle" fixed gear, which means two gears that are switched by changing the front chainring and flip-flopping the rear wheel with the help of a 15" wrench ‚Äî pretty much the same way it was done 100 years ago, before Campagnolo introduced shifters, derailleurs, and all that stuff.
My GoFundMe project didn‚Äôt reach its goal, so I had neither the time nor the money to get all the right parts. Instead of the proper 110 BCD cranks I used before, I had to go with 135 BCD. That leaves me with gears of 46x14 and 39x24 ‚Äî so climbing will be a bit harder than I‚Äôm used to.
For the same reason, instead of new bags I had to rely on leftovers from the stolen bike that the thieves left behind: a rear bag that used to be a handlebar bag (easy to reach), and handlebar bags that are basically a Frankenstein mix of several different models. The frame bag was handmade at the very last moment with glue and a needle out of an Ikea bag. The same goes for the front panniers, which I cut from a plastic shopping bag ‚Äî waterproof and with plenty of space.
The rear rack is a low-pro bullhorn. Not great as ergonomic handlebars for long-distance cycling, but fine for carrying heavy loads when touring. For bedding I have a sleeping mat made of thermal insulation material, a bivvy bag, a safety blanket, and a couple of garbage bags.
I‚Äôm also carrying a lot of tools, spare parts, and so on, so the whole setup is quite heavy. But after its first 600 km on the way to the start of TPR, it‚Äôs holding up alright.

: I'll be riding a BMC URS gravel bike for the GBDURO.
Groupset is a SRAM RED / X01 AXS mullet setup, with an AbsoluteBlack chainring.
Zipp 303 XPLR Wheels, the front is built onto a SON 28 hub dynamo, rear is build onto a Hope Pro 5 hub, Panaracer Gravelking X1 Plus tyres in 45mm.
Zipp XPLR handlebars,  Zipp Vuka aero bars with 50mm risers. Profile Design armpads and a Raceware mount for the Hammerhead GPS.
Exposure Revo / Redeye dynamo lights with Cateye AMPP 500 as backup.
Restrap Aero front bag and Race seatpack, custom made frame pack with Apidura Reservoir.
Altura top tube bag keeps my powerbank, Igaro charger and snacks close at hand.
Garmin InReach Mini tracker.
Key items of kit
: Sleep system is in the Restrap Aero front bag, Nordisk Lofoten tent, Rab Mythic 180 sleeping bag, Alpkit Numo mat.
I had the frame pack custom made by a friend, go check out @mrvear on Instagram. It's exactly what I asked for.
The lower compartment houses a Apidura reservoir, and the upper has custom Velcro straps to stop tent poles rattling. There's a large compartment on the non drive side, and three mesh pockets for snacks.
Clothes are in the Restrap Race seatpack.
I should hopefully be reasonably self sufficient with power, with a SON 28 hub dynamo.
This will power my Exposure Revo & Redeye lights at night, and charge my powerbank via a Igaro charger during the day.
A lightweight, super packable Rab Cinder Phantom waterproof, and a Albion Visibility Cargo vest for riding into the night and carrying extra food on long sections without resupply finish off the kit list.

Bikes Of Transcontinental Race No11
25 July, 2025
For the eleventh edition of the Transcontinental Race, we see a longer distance than ever totalling an approximate 5,000km and five control points and parcours between the start in Santiago de Compostela, Spain and Constanta, Romania. Follow along with the
commentary here
from the DotWatcher team and veterans as the race unfolds in its new chapter.
We'll dig into the statistics of the bikes and equipment in the coming few days (keep an eye on our socials), but without an in-depth analysis it's clear to see the trend towards wider tyres. Long gone are the days of 28mm feeling progressive, more riders are on tyres between 40-44mm tyres than those riding sub-30mm tyres.
Good luck to all those tackling the race on Sunday evening, we'll be following closesly for your whole journeys.

But it is still very much a touring bike: steel frame and fork, 26in wheels with SON28 dynamo front hub, 3x8 groupset (midrange Shimano) with front friction / rear indexed thumb shifters (Microshift), a well-worn Brooks B17 saddle, and don't forget the flat handlebars.
I have added some aerobars (Pro Missile) alongside the Ergon GP5 grips for comfort and swapped out the flat pedals for a set of SPDs. I've also replaced the touring-classic but heavy Schwalbe Marathon tyres with a set of Continental Race Kings: an unorthodox choice for a road race, certainly, but I liked the feel of them better than any of the road tyres I could find in 26‚Äù, and who knows, maybe they'll help me out on the gravel parcours.
There‚Äôs no prize for heaviest bike as far as I‚Äôm aware, but I imagine this would be in contention at 15.5kg (just the bike, without bags or water). I'm hoping what it lacks in speed it will make up for in durability.
Key items of kit
: My kit list is pretty standard (required items plus emergency bivvy + mat, basic layers for weather, first aid & repair kits), leaning towards the minimal in a probably futile attempt to compensate for how heavy the bike already is.
Aside from the bicycle itself, the least conventional item is probably the CrankTank4, which saves me from my least favourite cycling activity (reaching down for water bottles). It also serves as a reliable conversation starter when passers-by ask if it‚Äôs a petrol tank.

body:

Bike of the Tour Divide: DotWatcher Team Edition
13 June, 2025
Covered By: Kirsten Cluley
Kirsten's Tour Divide Bike
In 2024,
Kirsten Cluley
rode the Tour Divide finishing as 4th woman overall in 22 days 7 hours and 11 minutes. This is a mammoth amount of time to be out on the road and as native Scot, Kirsten spent as much time as she could out under the stars.
Battling freezing temperatures, raging storms and then extreme heat, this race took riders from border to border in the USA. With over 20 days of riding there was snow at the Northern ends of the route, with Kirsten struggling with the cold. Only then to be basked in the warmth of the desert, but don't let that fool you - it get's cold overnight!
Take a look at how she tackled cold, kept her bike maintained and survived the Divide.

Mezcal tyres are quick. Hope flat pedals (flats work for me, seems like I help knees and better for hike a bike). Bike is about 9.5 kg.

: Alpkit stingray frame bag and restrap top tube bag have enough space for everything I need. SOL escape bivvy along with a lightweight liner and Klymit Inertia mat keep weight down. Gore shakedry jacket, Oakley prescription sunglasses, fiveten freerider pro are favourite items of mine. New water to go filter bottle means I only need one bottle which fits nicely beneath the saddle with space for it to drop 100mm. Bikes of Across Andes: Patagonia Verde 2024
23 November, 2024
Just when you thought the 2024 bikepack racing season was over, the southern hemisphere's kicks off! Across Andes returns to Patagonia Verde for the second time to tackle the Carretera Austral and some gravel road detours along Chilean Patagonia's iconic fjords and densely forested mountains with a few gaucho towns along the way.
Have a browse below to see what riders are taking for this 950km route on some often-toured Patagonian gravel over the next week.

body:

Bikes of the Tour de Farce 2024
15 October, 2024
Covered By: Beccy Waters
This is certainly the most unorthodox Bikes of feature we‚Äôve ever released. There are no high resolution photos of glamorous bicycles propped up in front of beautiful landscapes here, instead things are a little different and you can take that as a precursor for the event itself. By design and execution, this event throws the status quo to the wind; from inception to finish very little resembled a mainstream bikepacking event.
The four stage event started on Saturday 28th of September in the Highlands with many peculiarities which you can learn more about at the
race page
. At the registration in the Inverness Youth Hostel on Friday afternoon, riders were challenged with filling in their own rider top trump which would later be used to calculate their privilege tax. Riders needed to fill in some simple details about themselves, draw their bike from memory and answer some more nuanced questions about a range of topics from their family‚Äôs sporting background, their method of travel to the event, and details about their bike‚Äôs quality, age and value, amongst many other things on which they would later be judged.
Enjoy browsing below to see some standout drawing skills from a handful of bikepackers and an insight into the first of the quirks of the Tour de Farce.

body:

Bikes of Two Volcano Sprint 2024
10 October, 2024
Two Volcano Sprint has evolved into Europe's season closer, often attracting some of the finest names from the European circuit who attend with fatigue in their legs from a heavy race calendar. It's become an aggressively fast race with many riders pushing for one last win to set them up for a winter's training. It's also notorious for being an ultra-racer's dream with good Italian food never too far away.
For the first time since it's inception in 2019, the 2VS will be held as a free route incorperating 6 mandatory parcours. This could influence bike choices, with some opting for gravel shortcuts by choice, whilst all will have to face an off-road stretch of 14km at the end of parcours no.6. This year there will be a rider award for Most Adventurous, so this may also encourage some gravel setups and chunky tyres.

Bikes of Trans Pyrenees Race 2024
23 September, 2024
This Pyreneen double traverse takes in some of the finest gravel roads between the Atlantic and the Mediterranean, as well some of the roughest! With occasional hike-a-bike, unpredictable weather and an elevation:distance ratio to make your heart skip a beat, it‚Äôs a balancing act of science and art to pack for this wild race.
Starting in Girona for the first time, riders will tackle a westerly Pyreneen traverse to San-Sebasti√°n before turning round and following much of the Raid Pyrenean route back to where it all began almost 2,000km earlier in Girona. There are four control points and five parcours riders must tackle, but they are free to route between these points. Regardless of which way they cut it, this will always be a hilly route and hefty elevation cannot be avoided. Optimising between weight and correct equipment for the mountains is indeed a well-honed skill.
Follow along
with the race as it unfolds from Friday morning with commentary from veteran riders Samuel Thompson and Lucas Becker.

I'm running a GRX setup with a 30/46 - 34 ratio, even lower than last year so I can save my knees and spin to my heart's content up all the steep climbs. I've gone for Pirelli Cinturato AllRoads, tubeless, obvs, which I've tested on both road and gravel and love, although I'm deploying my typical gravel avoidant tactics on my route this year. I also run TRP spyre mechanical discs, a controversial preference of mine (to hydraulics) which I think are the best of both worlds and perform 10/10 when set up with Jagwire cabling. Illyrian Loop is an unsupported bikepacking event of about 550 kilometres that will take place in Albania. The route will go through gravel and secondary roads in the most scenic routes of north Albania including reservoirs, forests and cultural heritage and historical sites.

Key items of kit
: I bought a used Stevens Gavere 2017 60cm frame from a friend (too big for my size...) - and the journey of building my bike for Sneak Peaks begun.
The bike originally had a 105 setup, but as I was expecting loads of elevation, I was looking for a different groupset. The gravel groupsets besides being expensive did not offer enough range (apart from the electronic ones that are $$$). A mullet seemed to be the best option, as I really wanted drop bars. But again it was difficult to find the right group set combination, and adapters seemed to sketchy for this adventure. I found a Chinese groupset, the Sensah SRX 1x11 and with 34x52 gearing it seemed like the best option. After collecting it myself from customs and fiddling a lot with internal cable routing, I got it mounted onto the bike, even though shifting is sometimes a bit off still. As for the wheels I was looking for a bit wider rims for my planned tubeless setup (Conti terra trail 40mm) and went for the trusted DT Swiss R500db. Combined with a shutter precision dynamo hub, I hope to be prepared to ride through the nights with a 75lux LED frontlight. I soldered a dynamo USB charger to charge my devices on the go, but cooling the circuit did not work out, so I ended up buying a dynamo charger for that reason. For the brakes I went for a hybrid disc brake solution: cable actuated but oil pressured. Finding the right ones to fit the frame was difficult though (flat mount vs post mount on this older frame). With mountain bike pedals and lots of water (bottles are missing in the picture), I am looking forward to climb the mountains. Building the bike was fun (and I know every screw and how to fix it), but riding it is even better!

Bike
: Having started cycling in the hilly Taunus in 2016 and living at the foot of the black forest for 3 years, now, I am no stranger
to inclines. Shifting my focus on and off the road to longer and longer day rides and introducing bikepacking to the game in 2019 started my obsession with route planning. Consider me a komoot ultra. Having helped to make the Orbit360 routes even more enjoiable, I had an early glance at Rapha's newest project and the hype never let me go. I have ridden a few Orbits and enjoyed a couple of trips of up to seven days (e.g. Route des Grandes Alpes) in central Europe over the years, but the SNEAK PEAKS ENTR√âE is going to be my first bikepacking race and surely also my biggest challenge so far.
I built this bike just recently, so I unfortunately do not have a better picture, yet. This bike is specifically built for adventures. It is a Genesis Vagabond drop bar MTB steel frame with a fully mechanical Apex 1*11 groupset (30t) that I tweaked with a Deore 11-46 cassette to get me up to those SNEAK PEAKS. The wheels are heavy and somewhat wide aluminium DTSwiss Gravel LN I lifted from my Canyon Grail AL and they do the job. They get stopped by TRP Spyre brakes with 180/160mm discs. I run 2.25" Mezcals - with tubes - and about 1.2/1.3bar. As a roady I could not resist to fit 40cm wide, only slightly flared bars and slam that 100mm stem. The ride is still more than comfy, though. Another roady thing might be my Favero Powermeters. This bike is not light, but it suits my demands. It is a finisher and I love it!
Key items of kit
: I fitted a mix of my old Ortlieb bags and my two newer frame bags from Apidura's Backcountry series plus a tool bottle under the downtube. It can still carry three 950ml bottles on the fork and seattube and for supermarket pillages I will borrow my girlfriend's Apidura musette. I navigate with a Garmin Edge 530 supported by Garmin's powerbank mounted to its bottom. For SNEAK PEAKS I will ride Vaude AM Tsali Mid STX shoes for long-term comfort, wheather protection and hike-a-bike-ability.

Apidura Race series long top tube bag and 4l frame bag and my trusty Tailfin carbon rack. I use Tailfin packing cubes to keep all items organized and that makes me much more efficient when I need to get stuff from the Tailfin. For sleeping I will go for a SOL Escape Thermo bivvy, with Sea To Summit Ultralight sleeping pad, Sea To Summit Aeros Premium pillow and Sea To Summit Reactor Extreme sleep liner. First time I will leave my Sea To Summit SP1 at home. I might put on a couple of smaller bags on the front; one Revelate Designs feed pouch for food and drink (and occasionally for keeping my GoPro handy) and a Revelate Designs Egress front pocket to store all my bits and pieces for photo and video. And of course my Exposure Strada to light up the night and Exposure Joystick as backup. On the back I have a couple of small Sigma and Blackburn rear lights.

Key items of kit
: I've upgraded to the Tailfin rear rack. So far, it has saved me so much time by eliminating any faff with packing, tightening straps, and searching in the bag. Well worth the extra weight!
Other than that, the wheels are hand-built by Adey Dent from off-the-shelf parts, making them easy to fix in most bike shops. Fitted to them are Michelin 28mm Power Cup TLR tires. I've got a 65mm stack height in my aero bars for all-day comfort and aero gains! I'm not running a handlebar bag as I need to save every watt possible! I have two 750ml water bottles and an emergency packable 1l water bottle in my rear pack. Up front, the lights are the Cateye Amp 1100 and Amp 400. The rear light is the Knog Cobber, along with two wearable Cateyes on the bag.
Clothing-wise, my highlight is my Albion cargo bibs‚ÄîI've never worn anything so comfortable. My jersey is my Poole Wheelers No Pinz Pro 1 Jersey. It's my lucky charm. The messages of support and dot watchers from the club will get me through any low moments!

Tires are Vittoria Zaffiro pro, 32 mm, with tubes and sealant inside the tubes. The groupset is a Shimano GRX 400/600, with 10 speeds. Crankset 46/30. Casette 11-36. On the handlebar, a Easton for gravel, there are aerobars, a mix of Profile design ergo with Ritchey bars.
Key items of kit

In the frame bag, that is from AGU, I have the electronic stuff: powerbank 20.000, plugs and cables. Also a liner sleeping bag and emergency blanket.
Attached to the handlebars i have two small bags (one from Line and the other it's from Decathlon), with a poncho for rain, towel, toiletry bag, winter gloves, winter cap, light rain jacket.
Both sides of the stem, there are tow bags from decathlon for food, a bike lock, a spoon to eat tones of food, a knife...
Lights: Main light is a Lezyne 1300 XXL, placed on the aerobars. On the helmet, i carry a headlamp, and a rear light. On the bike, two more rear lights.
Bike has a total of 5 bottle cages. One is for bike tools, two for water, and another two that can carry carbs and recovery dust, or water.
On my back, I carry also a trail runner vest from Salomon, to put more food, and some gifts that i want to buy by the route for some friends.

: Nothing about my setup or bike is the lightest but then again nor am I! I've got a set of Restrap bags which have done me well and an Alpkit top tube bag. For navigation I've given in to the bike computer thing and have picked up a Garmin Edge Explore 2. Lezyne bike lights, head torch and a hefty Lezyne front light for any night riding(??). Various puncture repair kit and a couple spare inner tubes, along with other bike spares.
Sleeping wise, I've borrowed my pals Wild Country Laser Compact 1 tent (thanks Cam) which is a cracker and I'll try my best not to put a hole in it. Sleeping bag, Cloud Base mat and pillow (I'm planning on sleeping), Alpkit's teeny Kraku stove and their pan. title: Bikes of Lakes ‚Äòn‚Äô Kn√∂del 2024
body:

Bikes of Lakes ‚Äòn‚Äô Kn√∂del 2024
31 July, 2024
This first edition of Lakes ‚Äòn‚Äô Kn√∂del is set to be an exciting event in an area that's been crying out for bikepacking events for years. The borderlands between Austria and Switzerland offer some of Europe's finest riding through the Alpine landscapes and some champagne gravel. This inaugural event has attracted 167 riders to its start list who will be lining up on the shores of Fuschlsee in Austria and riding across the Austrian/Swiss border a handful of times before finishing at Lake Constance in Switzerland.
This fixed 750km gravel route prioritises the riding experience, community spirit and culinary art is dubbed as ideal for a rookie rider thanks to the plentiful accommodation and excellent food at the mountain refuges. As the name implies, there‚Äôs also plenty of opportunity for some swimming and cooling off in the summer sun.
The event has incentivised green travel to and from the event by offering entry discounts to those who reach the start line via train and bike. This is an excellent example of a new race writing their own rules and encouraging the behaviours they would like to see expanded within the sport.

Bikes of Utrecht Ultra 2024
31 July, 2024
This epic ride combines the thrill of exploration with the challenge of endurance. Starting in Utrecht, we‚Äôll head south on a set route into beautiful Belgium, and then tackle three checkpoints and parcours in the stunning Belgian Ardennes and Germany's Eifel region.
The journey ends back in Utrecht, where memories and miles meet.
Given the road terrain and relatively flat nature of the course, this feature is packed with some of the fastest setups we‚Äôve ever seen. Blink and you‚Äôll miss them!
Follow along

Bikes Of Transcontinental No10
18 July, 2024
The TCR is widely regarded as the birthplace of competitive bikepacking in Europe following Mike Hall‚Äôs founding in 2013 and it‚Äôs grown immensely since then. From thirty intrepid riders gathering on London Bridge at the inaugural 2013 race to more than three hundred and fifty at last year‚Äôs edition, TCR is undoubtedly one of the cornerstones of the bikepacking calendar and this year is as exciting as it gets with new and familiar locations for rookies and veterans alike.
For the first time in the race‚Äôs history, riders will be departing from the iconic Roubaix Velodrome, Northern France, on their European journey to Istanbul, T√ºrkiye via four control points in Slovenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo and √áanakkale, T√ºrkiye.

Bike
: Hopefully this is the bike that I'll ride for the 2024 Elevation Vercors. I spent all winter and spring thinking I'll go with my full rigid MTB (Kona Unit X), but some discussions with the organizers made me switch to my beloved titanium gravel, a Sauvage Lapiste from. Depending on the weather right before the start and the detailed route which will be revealed in a few days, I still may change my mind.
Back to the bike then. I got the frameset with a carbon fork in early 2021, and built it myself with pieces from a previous bike and what I could find in a post-pandemic bike shortage era. I've got Hunt gravel wheels with a SON dynamo and 44 mm Mezcal tyres that I got specifically for the event. That's the max clearance the frame was given with, and it's quite close at the rear (I usually go with 35-40 mm tyres and jump on the Unit for more hardcore gravel). The drivetrain is GRX, a 46-30 chainring and a 11-40 sunrace cassette, which I also got for the event, since I usually ride with a 11-34, which seemed a bit short for all the elevation gains we'll have to face. For the rest I have second-hand Ultegra brakes, Deda aerobars, titanium seatpost and stem. I trained with both flat and spd pedals, and I intend to go with the flat ones.
Key items of kit
:  For the bags It's mostly Apidura, with top-tube, frame and saddle expedition packs; I also have a stem bag from decathlon on the left side of the bike, and two cargo cages on the fork for a quick acess to a long-sleeve kit and rain/wind jacket. Food will be in the frame and stem bags. No sleeping bag for me, I have a bivy and more layers with the repair kit in the saddle pack, I think it will be enough for a couple hours naps. For the night, I have Busch & Muller lights (dynamo powered) with a built-in USB charger.

It took me a whole year to build this bike, it all started with the design on bikecad. Then there was the choice of parts, so I have the only groupset Camplagnolo record single chainring, I replaced all the bearings with ceramic bearings.
My seat post and handlebars are carbon sworks.
I have a ChrisKing headset.
my saddle and mirror are from the BERTOUD brand
Once I succed the medecine school exam I bought customized wheels and a system to be self-sufficient in electricity, I have a front and rear headlight from son and a forumslader to charge my devices (he is a German geek who created this to be able to charge your devices with fast charging even when you are stopped). This entire system is powered by a son dynamo.
Key items of kit
: I wanted the most optimized bags for my needs (I'm a psychopath for order and optimization). I learned to sew from my grandmother when I was younger, so I just took out my sewing machine. My bags are made of dynema, XPAC, parachute canvas and wake board sail.
in the saddle bag I have SEA TO SUMMIT a ‚ÄúReactor Extreme Sleeping Bag Liner‚Äù.
in the wheel bag there is a very easy-to-access rain windbreaker.
in the frame bag there is a bivi from SOL, my mattress, a spare shorts and a spare jersey?
in the downtube container there is my repair equipment, my toiletry bag and my reflective vest.
in my top tube bag there is a jacket, my arm warmers, my gloves for the cold, and a space for food.
between my extensions bars there is a sort of aero food pouch which I will use to put all kinds of things (food, drinks)

Bike
: I will be going out with my T-Lab X3, custom-made titanium frame in Montreal with Boyd Jocassee gravel wheels and Rene Herse Bon Jon Pass in 35mm. There is a SON 28 dynamo hub in front, powering a Sinewave Cycles Beacon and Supernova E3 Taillight. Groupset is Sram Force AXS (Rival AXS for the 160mm crank) in 10-36 & 33-46 in front. The frame and food pouch bags are from Copra Bikepacking and are custom-made for the bike in Paris. Saddle and top tube bags are from Apidura's racing serie, although I might switch out the saddlebag for the expedition version as it seems it is going to be a wet and cold trip and I might need to pack more warm layers!
A change from two years ago during the Three Peaks include the Revelate Pronghorn front bag, which holds my sleeping kit (sleeping bag, liner, mattress, bivvy...). I am still wondering how this will turn out with the storms planned so far... If needed, I'll swap the sleeping kit for some more clothes in the front and will leave with the racing saddlebag.
Answers on the final choice on Friday morning when we will be departing!

Comfy comfy profile Aerobars for comfywomfiness and to give sone variety for my poor, numb hands üôÑ. Flared ergo grips, mini barends. Bikes of Taunus Bikepacking No.7 2024
12 June, 2024
This mixed-terrain 1,000km challenging route has been coined ‚ÄúJesko‚Äôs rollercoaster‚Äù as the Taunus hills, which are not high mountains, are full of relentless up and down which are more than enough to wear bikes and riders out. Typically, only about 50 to 60 percent of riders make it to the finish line. The climbing is relentless. Blown-up knees and sore achilles heels are testament to the demanding nature of the course.
Riders will pass over a wild mix of gravel roads, asphalt lanes, cobblestone alleys and forest trails. They will be treated to a tour of this region‚Äôs history including remains of the Roman empire‚Äôs last frontier, medieval towns, deserted army depots and defunct slate mines.
Follow along with the
race commentary here
.

Key items of kit

Ren√© Herse Fleecer Ridge tires are mounted on a SON/Newman wheelset built by Light-Wolf Studio. The dynamo is connected to a Sinewave Beacon light with a USB charger. What else? A Vecnum suspension stem, 50 cm Dropbar from Curve, and ZIPP Vuka Aerobar.
Key items of kit
: Bags are a mix from Apidura (Top), Salsa (Frame), Revelate Designs (Back), and Restrap (Aerobar). For navigation, I use a Garmin Edge 1040. For sleeping, I use a Borah Gear Cuben Bivy, the Sea to Summit Spark sleeping bag, and a sleeping mat from Sea to Summit. If the weather is bad, I prefer to stay in a hotel üòä. I wear a mix of Maap, Mons Royale, and Pearl Izumi clothes. If it is cold, I have a vest from Odlo, Merino arm and leg warmers, and a Patagonia Micro Puff Jacket. If it is wet, I have a Gore jacket and Endura pants.

Handbuilt custom wheelset by myself, rims are Roval C38, Sapim CX-Ray blade spokes, DT 370 hub in the back, and in the front, one SON 28 Disc Dynamo Hub. The dynamo hub supplies a Supernova M99 DYPro and a Cinq Plug 5 USB-C charging adapter with power, no power banks required. To ensure the two consumers do not interfere with each other, a mechanical switch has been connected in between, allowing you to decide which of the two gets power. During the day, the USB charger is used, and in the evening, the lamp. The lamp is attached to the GoPro mount and the charging adapter sits in the front of the frame bag.
A 45mm G-One R tire is mounted on both the front and rear wheels, tubeless setup.
Setup complete weight without catering: 13.5kg
Key items of kit
: The key element of the setup is the dynamo hub. The light supply is always guaranteed, and the charging adapter makes this setup completely self-sufficient, which simplifies long periods in remote areas. You can better concentrate on the essentials: pedaling and eating.
Apart from that, I mainly focused on weight for all the other pieces of equipment: a Therm-a-Rest NeoAir UberLite sleeping pad, Sea to Summit Spark 0 summer sleeping bag, an Evoc hydration pack, and a Lupine Piko helmet light. The particularly small chainring with 36T in the front and the large cassette with 52T allow this bike to be ridden uphill for a very long time, perfect for this event, I think.

body:

Bikes of Blaenau 600 2024
6 June, 2024
A truly Welsh 600km upland adventure through some of the land's finest off-road sewn together with characteristically hilly tarmac, including the Brecons, Berwyns, Black Mountains, Cambrians and Snowdonia. This year, the event is accompanied by the first edition of a women's rally which thirteen women have signed up for.
Commentary will be written by local lass and veteran, Molly Weaver. Follow along
here
.

Age
: 38

Dave Johnson
Age

Location
: Cleobury Mortimer, Shropshire
Bike
: An oddball, homebuilt, rigid, singlespeed! A Lynskey Ridgeline ti frame mated to Torus ti forks and seatpost.
Currently setup with a 34t Hope oval chainring and Surly 20t cog for climbing the Welsh hills (hopefully)!
Brakes, crankset and bottom bracket are also from Hope.
The 29er wheels were built by Andy at Clee Cycles- Stans Arch rims and Hope hubs, the rear being singlespeed/trials specific.
Handlebars are high riser from Stooge cycles.
Finally the saddle is a Brooks C17.

Bikes of Highland Trail 550 2024
24 May, 2024
The Highland Trail 550 is one of the most hotly anticipated races in the European calendar, it's notoriously difficult thanks to the technical riding, Scottish inclement weather, lengthy hike a bike and rivere crossings.
This 550 mile route has, for the second year in a row, attracted a 50:50 gender split and there is a total of 62 riders lining up in Tyndrum on Saturday morning. The route follows three loops of the highlands and the first half will lure the rookies into a false sense of security with plenty of rideable singletrack and fast estate roads. The second half is much less forgiving and often where the real race starts.
Follow along with commentary
from  Philippa Battye and Alice Lemkes, first and second women from last year. There's sure to be a few laughs along the way and maybe even a meme!
Quinda Verheul
Age
: 34
Location
: Rotterdam, Netherlands
Bike
: The bike I‚Äôll be riding is a Sour full-suspension prototype, which has 120mm travel front and rear. It‚Äôs equipped with Fox suspension and Hope components. For the tires, I‚Äôm running Schwalbe XC tires. The drivetrain has a 10-52T cassette paired with a 30T chainring.
Key items of kit
: I‚Äôll be packing my gear in a Tailfin R&D AeroPack, frame bag, and front roll made custom for the bike. I‚Äôll also have a supply vest from Carrie Gere, and for quick access to snacks, I‚Äôm using feed bags from Wit Slingers.
Given the recent ride, a midge net is a must-have! For weather protection, I‚Äôll be wearing an Arc‚Äôteryx rain jacket and pants, paired with Sealskinz socks and Black Diamond waterproof overmitts.

title: Bikes of The Accursed Race 2024
body:
DotWatcher.cc
Event Commentary
Results
Event Calendar
Features
About Us
Bikes of The Accursed Race 2024
14 May, 2024
What would you pack for an inaugural race in the Balkans? Lost Dot‚Äôs first edition of the Accursed Race started this morning from Shkod√´r, Albania. This 1,600km off-road route is a rideable addition to the growing racing scene in south eastern Europe. It has been years in the making and takes riders to the Balkans, a part of the continent that Lost Dot Race Coordinator, Andrew Phillips, calls the spiritual heart of the Transcontinental Race.
There‚Äôs very little that‚Äôs certain about an inaugural race in such a relatively untravelled part of Europe, and riders are certainly packing for the unknown! All bikes look to be suitably equipped for the rigours of off-road riding with a healthy mix of drop bars, flat bars and varying tyre widths. Some have opted for a racked system, while others a more traditional bikepacking setup with a saddle pack.
Our very own Beccy Waters will be writing commentary with support from equally uninitiated TCR veterans! Follow along with the
commentary here
.
Oliver Neumann
Age
: 47
Cap number
: 16
Location
: Freiburg/Germany
Bike
: Salsa Stormchaser 52.5, Intend Samurai GR with 60 mm travel, Shimano GRX 1x11, front caliper Shimano SLX 4 piston 180mm disc, rear caliper Shimano GRX 2 piston 160mm disc, SON dynamo hub 15x110, and Ren√© Herse Juniper Ridge tyres 48x584.
Key items of kit
: Ortlieb bags: 2x Fork Pack 4.1L, 1x Fuel Pack, 1x Frame Pack RC 4L, and 1x Handlebar Pack QR. Vaude bag: Trailsaddle.
Andrew Hatton
Age
: 56
Cap number
: 26
Location
: London, United Kingdom
Bike
: Scott Aspect 910, 29er, not particularly fancy or light but hopefully reliable, lovingly fettled into its current spec by my LBS in Putney. Features Rockshox Judy 100mm forks and a Cane Creek Thudbuster seat post, hopefully taking a bit of the sting out of the Accursed. It boasts a very much mixed groupset including SRAM NX cranks and an Eagle XG 10-52 cassette for the ups and downs, alongside Shimano MT220 brakes/rotors for the stopping power. Running tubeless Vittoria Mezcal 29 x 2.25 tires on aluminum rims.
Key items of kit
: A mix of Ortlieb and Restrap bags, essentially what I've acquired over the last few years. Lights are from Outbound Lighting, a great company based in Chicago, known for their excellent trail lights. My sleep system leans towards the luxury end of the market, featuring a Raab Raider Hooped Bivvy, Exped sleeping mat, Alpkit sleeping bag, and a Thermarest down pillow - the whole ensemble offering almost as much space and comfort as my small London flat. My lucky item, hopefully not needed but just in case, is a tick remover!
Adrien Liechti
Age
: 39
Cap number
: 12
Location
: On the road
Bike
: BOMBTRACK Cale AL
Key items of kit
: I'll be racing the Accursed on my Bombtrack Cale AL 2024, equipped with a tuned Fox 34 fork, DT Swiss 1200 XMC wheels, Rene Herse Fleecer Ridge 55mm Endurance tires, a 12-speed Shimano XT groupset, and a full Apidura setup from the Backcountry series.
Christopher Ri√ümann
Age
: 35
Cap number
: 21
Location
: Berlin, Germany
Bike
: For the inaugural Edition of the Accursed Race i am going to ride my newly build Bike for the first Time! The Base is a Bombtrack Beyond +2. I hooked it up with Hunt Race XC 29inch Wheels, although it is originally a 650b Frame. Only thing i had to change is the SID SL Ultimate Fork. Groupset is Sram GX Eagle. Brakes are Shimano SLX. I have opted for a mixed Vittoria Setup of 2,1 Barzo in the Front for extra Grip and 2,25 Mezcal in the Back for better rolling. For comfort Ergonomics i have choosen Ergon SM Pro Saddle and SQ Labs 710 Grips to be comfortable for the longest Time possible.
Key items of kit
: My Bag Setup is Mix of different Brands. Aero Pack and Down Tube is Tailfin. Fullframe Restrap Bag, a small Topeak Toptube Bag and a Foodpouch by Blackburn. A Supernova m99 DY Pro powerd by a SON 28 Dynamo will be lighting my nights. Cars will be attracted by Exposure Lights Blaze MKII. For the first Time i will use a Dynamo powerd USB charger - the Fahrradlader v3.1 combined with a passthrough Batterypack. Sleeping Setup is Basic lightweight Therm-a-Rest Sleeping Pad, trusty Carinthia Sleeping Bag and a Budget SOL Escape Bivy.
Thomas Chateau
Age
: 48
Cap number
: 22
Location
: Le Mans / France
Bike
: Fairlight Secan 2.0 (Reynolds 853 steel bike) featuring a Shimano 2x11 GRX800 transmission with 44/28 TA Specialit√© chainrings, Shimano XT 11/40 cassette, and Shimano XT trail pedals. It rolls on Hunt alloy 650b wheels with Teravail Rutland 27.5x2.1 durable tubeless tires. Equipped with a SON28 Dynamo, Igaro D2 USB converter, SON lights, and Knog+ rear blip. It boasts a Chris King headset, FSA cockpit with Arundel Rubber Gecko bar tape, Crane bellring, and Deda Parabolica bar-ends. Finished with a Brooks C17 carved all-weather saddle and three bottles.
Key items of kit
: Outfit: Kask Mojito helmet, Rapha Brevet bib & Explore zip neck technical shirt, Brevet merino socks, Fizik Terra Ergolace shoes, Rapha Explore gilet, Sea to Summit ultralight bag.
Apidura/Rapha handlebar bag (with Sea to Summit 70D dry bag): Outdoor Research Helium bivy, Sea to Summit ultralight mat, Pajak Radical X sleeping bag, Cocoon Thermolite liner.
Helmut √âquipement frame bag: Lezyne caddy for identity card and money (euro, lek, konvertible marks), phone, cables and chargers, Zendure 10.000 "Mini" and Anker 10.000 "533" power banks, tools, Squirt lube, Lezyne pump and tyre patches, Orange Sealant refill, Maxalami repair kit, 2 Continental light tubes, Supernova Airstream spare lights, Petzl Actik Core headlamp.
Helmut √âquipement saddle bag (on Carradice Bagman support with struts): Enlightenment Equipement Climashield warm jacket, Albion rain pants, BlackYak rain jacket, Loeffler GTX overshoes, PEdALED arm warmers, Rapha Merino things (baselayer, leg warmers, socks, spare jersey), toiletry and pharmacy kit, emergency blanket, food.
David Sanchez
Age
: 30
Cap number
: 19
Location
: Lausanne, Switzerland
Bike
: Felt Doctrine circa 2019, SRAM drivetrain with 30T x 10-50T gearing, Shimano SLX brakes, DT Swiss wheels with a SON dynamo hub, 2.2‚Äô‚Äô Continental Race King tires, Ergon grips paired with Pro Missile aerobars for comfort.
Key items of kit
: A salad mix of owned and borrowed Apidura bags, including a 2L bladder inside the frame bag and a 1L bottle on the downtube. Equipped with a Garmin 830 and eTrex 30x for backup navigation, with a Sinewave beacon paired with a Supernova light at the rear for visibility. Carrying an extra Apidura musette for resupplies in case of cycling-induced munchies. Sleeping gear includes a Sea to Summit ultralight air mat, Spark SP2 sleeping bag, and for the first time, an inflatable pillow. Enjoying offline curated music playlists on the phone for extra fun.
Konrad Kowara
Age
: 45
Cap number
: 7
Location
: The Netherlands
Bike
: Orbea Oiz TR fitted with a longer road stem and aero bars for optimal comfort. Mostly Shimano XT/XTR components and a 32T Raceface chainring. Rolling on a Maxxis Rekon Race tire at the front and a Wolfpack Speed at the back for a blend of resilience, grip, and rolling resistance.
Key items of kit
: Aeroe Spider back and front racks, along with a Restrap top tube bag. Embracing the brand anarchist spirit with lots of mismatching lights, tires, and bags. Sleeping kit consists of a bivvy and a sleeping bag.
Alexander Kopp
Age
: 37
Cap number
: 27
Location
: Innsbruck, Austria
Bike
: I will ride my Specialized Epic with an Intend Samurai Fork/Intend Hover OPT. Damper, PI ROPE/Beast Components XC25 Wheels, Continental Race King and Shimano 12-speed (30-51T).
Key items of kit
: Bags are from the awesome brand Tailfin. Lupine lite setup for the helmet/ Supernova for the handlebar, Cumulus sleeping bag, SFM mounts from Tailfin for the water bottles on the fork, a lot of motivation from my side.
Martin Zettel
Age
: 52
Cap number
: 4
Bike
: The Open U.P. bike is equipped with SRAM Force, DT Swiss GR1600 wheels, a 3T handlebar, Syntace Aerobar, and a Redshift stem.
Key items of kit
: Bags from Apidura and Tailfin, ZPack tent, Highlight sleeping bag, Knog (rear) and Lupine (front) lights, and Q36.5 clothes and shoes.
Nick Percival
Age
: 61
Cap number
: 09
Location
: Devon, UK
Bike
: Sonder Broken Road Ti. This bike has seen many adventures & I favour a small 28t oval chainring. SON dynamo drives the Exposure Revo light at night and Sinewave usb in the daytime. SQLab inner bar ends are a favourite of mine to give a great alternative position for resting the hands and altering the head & neck position.
Key items of kit
: Lots of Alpkit bags and kit including the custom frame bag with reflective piping. On this adventure I‚Äôm using a small Terra Nova tent if a bit of shelter is needed in the Accursed mountains. I‚Äôve moved the sleeping kit into the Tailfin rear pack this time as it‚Äôs heavier than the extra clothes and I don‚Äôt have any cooking gear.
Lutz Wellensiek
Age
: 21
Cap number
: 17
Location
: Germany
Bike
: ROSE Backroad SRAM AXS Mullet Build.
Key items of kit
: Jack the bike Rack in the front. Self made middle bag. And a saddlebag in the bag.
Ronny Roelandt
Age
: 59
Cap number
: 34
Location
: Geraardsbergen, Belgium
Bike
: Specialized Epic HT with fixed carbon fork, 11-speed (11-46) Shimano XT gear, and Alu DT-Swiss wheels with tubeless tires (front Schwalbe Thunder Burt/back Specialized Fast Trak).
Key items of kit
: Ride with GPS navigation system (Garmin Edge 1000 as backup), 2 power banks 27,000mAh, 4 bags in total, and 3 water bottles fixed to frame.
David Kealhofer
Age
: 33
Cap number
: 31
Location
: Z√ºrich, Switzerland
Bike
: I‚Äôm not sure if it‚Äôs better described as a vanilla setup or a noob setup. (Both are fair.) It‚Äôs a Canyon Exceed CF 5, basically stock, so 100 mm travel on a Rockshox Recon, 1x11 Shimano groupset, nothing exotic. The minor exceptions are a Salsa Rustler bar, a WTB Koda saddle, and a SON dynamo front hub on a DT Swiss XM 421 rim. Just for the race, I put on a set of new Ren√© Herse Fleecer Ridge tires and swapped on a left-side 4iii power meter, whose only, doomed purpose is to tell me more good news than bad. The final weight is a bit heavier than stock, thanks mainly to the dynamo. Not much deep thought went into this‚Äìit‚Äôs the bike I had, it‚Äôs plenty nice, it‚Äôs treated me pretty well, but I don‚Äôt really know what I‚Äôm getting into and I‚Äôm not gonna like buy a whole new bike, right?
Key items of kit
: My main carrying volume comes from a Restrap 14 L saddle bag and a Revelate Pronghorn front roll. Odds and ends go in the Apidura frame bag, snacks and toiletries in the Restrap stem bags, and most of the tools in the Apidura downtube bag. I‚Äôm bringing the Apidura packable musette for some extra snack capacity. I‚Äôve never used a bivy bag before because I am not really a loner/badass, so it‚Äôs dumb money talking, but I‚Äôm taking the OR Helium Bivy. The rest of the sleep kit is a Sea to Summit air mat and pillow, and a RAB bag. I‚Äôve found the bivy‚Äôs a lot comfier staked out, so I am bringing some stakes, too. Power is from a battery charged by the SON hub via a Sinewave Revolution. Primary front lighting is a SON Edelux, suspended above the front roll on an action camera mount, a little ridiculous, and from behind its assorted Knog blinkies. As for barely defensible creature comforts, I‚Äôm bringing a crummy mp3 player with corded headphones to rescue my phone‚Äôs battery from my thirst for tunes, a little tin of chamois cream, and a bulky but cozy hoodie to bring the mood up in the cool crepuscular times. Dry weight for the bicycle and kit is 23.4 kg.

I have kitted it out with DT Swiss M502 27.5er wheels laced into a DT350 rear hub and Shimano dynamo upfront. Pirelli Gravel M 2.0" tyres providing the grip and "suspension". : All bike luggage is from Apidura - frame and saddle bags along with two fuel pods on the top tube. I will also be taking a Salomon Trail 12L hydration backpack. Blistering hot temperatures during the day, high chances of rain and snow, and riding through the night are all things to be considered. Wahoo Elemnt Bolt for navigation, paired with Komoot maps on the phone as redundancy. I am using Cumulus Lite 200 sleeping bags paired with a Sea To Summit insulated sleeping mat.

Bikes of Seven Serpents 2024
11 May, 2024
A set-route race between seven checkpoints from Slovenia through Croatia and its islands finishing in Trieste, Italy along a mix of gravel and secondary roads. Last year's event was hampered by pre-event rain and mud, but the forecast this year looks much more pleasant. On the cards are 850km with 16,000m of climbing, a handful of which will be done on foot.
The 98 solo riders and 13 pairs tackle this gravel race starting at 7am on Sunday the 12th May, you can follow along with veteran Marcus Nicolson's

Bikes of Gravel Birds 2024
11 May, 2024
This year's Gravel Birds kicks off on Saturday morning for the 78 solo riders and 11 pairs across the 750km and l'Abetarda 250km. This gravel loop of the untouched Alentejo region in Portugal will take riders along the many hills of the region, the Guadiana Valley, to the Atlantic coast and inland again.

Bikes of Seven Serpents: Quick Bite! 2024
8 May, 2024
This Sunday morning at 7am, almost 200 riders will start the smoother and shorter little sibling to the Seven Serpents. In this 535km route, riders will summit almost 9,000m covering smooth gravel, mountain climbs and pass the wondrous caves and lakes of Slovenia, Croatia and head north for their final course in Trieste, Italy.
This short and sweet race promises plenty of climbing and the idyllic rugged Balkan roads. Read through this feature to see the bikes and equipment riders are donning for this weekend's gravel race through the Balkans. One rider is even using this event as part of their commute to the start of the inaugural no-fly Lost Dot race, The Accursed Race, in Shkod√´r, Albania on May 14th.
Follow along with veteran racer Roland Bartmuss's
commentary here
when the race starts on Sunday morning.

One of the flattest and windiest bikepacking races on the calendar demands a fast and aerodynamic approach to packing. Think: frame water tanks. With some opting to only use hotels, there are some very light setups taking to the line on Saturday morning.
After a year's hiatus for the race's inaugural gravel edition, we're back to the tarmac for one of the fastest races to dotwatch. Blink and you'll miss it!

Bikes of Gravel del Fuego 2024
13 April, 2024
Riders at Gravel del Fuego are packing for the southernmost bikepacking race where no race has ever gone before. Packing enough for a relatively fast race with extremely limited resupply will be an art. This 1,000km route on a mix of good gravel and asphalt
Riders have been allowed drop bags at the CP5 which for most simply includes food and inner tubes. Resupply is few and far between but riders are well aware of this. Additionally, there are no bike shops en route so a bag drop will also allow for some mid-race bike maintenance. The route shouldn‚Äôt be too hard on the bikes, providing it‚Äôs dry.

Bikes of The Unknown Race 2024
9 April, 2024
For the second edition of the Unknown Race little more is known than last year! The checkpoints change each year, as has the start/finish line for this edition, and are not released before the start. Riders will only find out the first checkpoint an hour before the start, the second CP at the first CP, and so on until they return back to Vienna approximately 1,000km later.
Last year's event saw temperatures overnight drop dramatically, particularly in the Alps' valleys, so riders will need to be equipped for varying spring weather in the mountains. This is made even more of an art given they don't yet know where they will be going.

Bikes of Dales Divide 2024
29 March, 2024
The Dales Divide has emerged as something of a season opener for the off-road calendar in the UK whilst also attracting foreign talent. It‚Äôs grown in popularity and competition enormously since its inception in 2019 and there‚Äôs rarely been a year where the record hasn‚Äôt been broken. For this year's edition, over 250 riders will be lining up.
Riders have the option of riding the full route from North England‚Äôs west coast town of Arnside to Scarborough on the east coast and back, totalling 600km, or they can opt for a shorter route of 400km but missing out on fish and chips in Scarborough!
Northern England‚Äôs moors and uplands are notorious for their inclement weather, especially in early spring, so read on to learn how riders are equipping themselves for this double traverse of some of the UK‚Äôs most exposed riding.
Follow along with
our commentary
from the ground by our Managing Editor, Kitty Dennis.

Bikes of GranGuanche Audax Gravel 2024
29 March, 2024
This 700km route goes by fast gravel roads and secondary paved roads while avoiding rocky singletrack or sandy sections. It's open to any kind of bike, but the organizers recommend gravel bikes with low gearing and a minimum of 40mm tires.
You will see from the submissions that the balance between speed, weight and comfort has resulted in a range of bikes with tyre choice being of particular interest and importance. Also considering the lack of natural water sources on the islands, the riders will have to rely on establishments and have the capacity to carry resources over distance.
Remember: this is not a race, it's an audax. But that doesn't stop some riders setting out to test their mettle!
Follow along with the
tracking here
.

The wheels are the excellent 650b Stayer Gravel Adventure wheels with a Son Delux dynamo front and a Hope RS4 rear hub. Running them low pressure tubeless with Vittoria Airliners and Schwalbe 2.1‚Äù Thunder Burt tyres.
Extra-comfort dept.: the Profile Design Sonic aerobars, a Redshift Shockstop stem holding the Lauf Smoothie handlebar and a Brooks C17 Carved saddle.

: Bags are a mix of Miss Grape (bar pouches), Restrap and Apidura bags above and below the top tube, the Wayward Riders Louise harness with a dry bag out back and a simple dry bag strapped to the ‚Äòbars with my sleep kit. No sleeping bag, just a SOL Escape bivvy, Sea to Summit Ultralight mat and my spare clothes to keep me warm. If it rains, will be looking to sleep under some kind of shelter!
Electrics will be charged by the dynamo, with K-Lite front and right lights, their USB charger and a pass-through battery to keep phone and Wahoo charged.

body:

Bikes of Tour Te Waipounamu 2024
29 January, 2024
Welcome to the third edition of the Tour Te Waipounamu! It's one of the most hotly anticipated races in the off-road bikepacking calendar and it's back after a hiatus in 2022. This year's lineup is looking better than ever with a handful of Australia's finest racers making the trip over the Tasman Sea and some from ever further afield. They'll be lining up against some of New Zealand's own talent for a showdown the length of Waipounamu (NZ's South Island).
The race demands meticulous preparation for 1,330km over mountain and valley in New Zealand's South Island where the riding is rough, resupply scarce and the weather unforgiving.
Follow along
with commentary from veteran racer and commentator Andrew Trevelyan.
Emma Flukes
Name
: Emma Flukes
Age
: 35
Location
: Hobart, Tasmania, Aus
Bike
: Pivot Les SL, size extra tiny. Fox Factory 34SC 100mm bounce fork. Shimano mixed XT/XTR brakes and driveline with 12-speed 32T x 10-51. DT Swiss carbon rims with DT240 hubs and Vittoria Mezcal 29x2.35 rubber. Cockpit of Thomson carbon bars with ESI foamie grips, BBB bar ends straight outta 1990. May run a QR clamp on my slender 27.2mm carbon seatpost for 3cm of drop when things get rowdy, still undecided. The wheels, cranks and frame are carpeted with commercial signage-grade reflective tape and vinyl so this thing lights up like a Christmas tree under headlights. No excuses for not seeing me :)
Key items of kit
: Kit is a wild mix of brands that just work. Kicking off with the bomber Oveja Negra Gearjammer saddle pack. Revelate feedbags, top tube and downtube bag. Apidura fork bags and packable backpack. Exposure front/helmet lights and Knog rear flashers. Garmin eTrex and Edge for nav redundancy and because I'm a nerd. inReach for safety. Sleep gear is a Montbell bivy, Therm-a-Rest pad, Z-Packs hoodless bag paired with a Katabatic Gear down hat thingo and Patagonia puffer. Sometimes I run cold so I carry A LOT of clothes, but I know this kit and I trust it to keep me safe.

Bikes of Across Andes 2023
18 November, 2023
In this edition of Across Andes, riders head further south than ever before to take in some of Chilean Patagonia‚Äôs most iconic gravel roads. Notorious amongst cycle-tourists in South America, the Carretera Austral is the chosen route when riding the length of the Andes due to its vistas and varying landscapes.
Riders' bikes were weighed at the registration earlier today and we can confirm the heaviest bike totals 22kg, whereas the lightest is Isidora Solari at a mere 13.75kg (without water). Only 500g heavier was Juliet Elliott's bike, also dry.
While most of Chile is littered with
tiendas
and
minimercados
making resupply relatively easy and reliable, this isn‚Äôt so true of the remote Carretera Austral and the offshoots riders will be tackling, especially out of high season. They will need to restock plentifully wherever possible. The forecast is so bleak they should have enough space for food as they‚Äôll be wearing most of their warm and waterproof gear at all times! Riders could be forgiven for hoping for warm weather to wrap up their northern hemisphere season or some sunshine if coming out of a southern hemisphere‚Äôs winter training, but the forecast is not looking kind to our riders; heavy rain, cold wind and unseasonably low temperatures during the day and night are predicted.
The outdoor shops of Coyhaique have been raided for their winter gloves, towels and waterproof socks which have been converted into winter overshoes. It‚Äôs unlikely anything that gets wet during the race is going to dry out, except for next to a fire in a hostel. The weather has altered many riders‚Äô kit lists and a few race plans.
Our very own Beccy Waters will be following the race from the ground so be sure to follow along as she brings the dots to life at

Bikes of GBDURO23
19 October, 2023
GBDURO is one of the premier mixed-terrain races in Europe with a few exciting twists. Organisers, The Racing Collective, have stayed true to its low-impact high-social ethos since its first edition in 2019; it implemented a #noflyride in 2020, has minimised the use of vehicles for media and now penalises riders for dropping any litter which is outkeeping with its leave no trace principle.
The route is unchanged since the event‚Äôs inception and riders continue to traverse many of the UK‚Äôs well-known and lesser known paths, tracks, bridleways and ancient routes sewn together with a healthy dose of tarmac to smooth the ride and toughen the bike choice!
The inclusion of three checkpoints en route influences riders‚Äô packing lists as they need to equip themselves to be comfortable and dry at the outdoor checkpoints. The very fastest riders can spend more time stationary at the CPs than riding which means GBDURO may pose the ultimate packing conundrum: pack light to go fast but spend longer waiting. Kit lists have been designed accordingly with more robust sleep setups and luxuries rarely seen at other races. Look out for pyjamas, sandals and other home comforts.
Don't miss any of the action (and inaction at the CPs) with
our commentary
from veteran podium finisher, Bryn Davies.
Nils Opgenorth
Name
: Nils Opgenorth
Age

Location
: Stuttgart, Germany
Bike
: I will be riding the GBDURO23 with my beloved Kona Sutra LTD. Even though the steel frame is not the lightest, it has demonstrated its robustness in many other journeys, and my familiarity with the frame should hopefully allow me to perform some repairs on the way if necessary. A 34T chainring in the front and a 10-42T cassette should hopefully do the trick to get me through the hilly parts of the UK. For tires I went with 45mm Schwalbe G-One R.
Key items of kit
: I spent some time organising the front of the bike and ended up with a DIY aero bag, which combines a simple drybag, straps and some 3d printed parts. In a burrito format, it holds a bivy and my sleeping kit, waiting to be rolled out at night :)

My drivetrain is 12sp Eagle XX1 with Sram Force controls paired with RatioTechnology.com 12sp conversion. The wheels are Enve with DT Swiss rear and SON28 front hubs built by DCRWheels.com and with Teravail Spawood 2.2 tyres as much for comfort as for speed. My seatpost is a Canyon VCLS 2.0 with flex for comfort too.  My bags are a mixture of Spoked-UK, Wildcat.cc and Alpkit but the majority made bespoke by WldSkyGear.co.uk from dynema-DCF for weight saving.  I run the dynamo hub through a Sinewave Beacon light that charges stuff and runs my eTrex GPS along with an Exposure Joystick for when it‚Äôs dark but too slow to produce much light.  Much of my bike setup is held together by cable ties and sticky tape!
Key items of kit
: Much of my cold weather down and sleep gear is PHDesigns.co.uk ‚Äì also from Yorkshire with a Teranova Ultra One tent and NeoAir pad if weather gets rough.  Most of the time with my shorts and jersey I‚Äôve only leg warmers, a few wool base layers and a Gore shakedry running top along with my famous two DalesDivide.co.uk buffs.  My ‚Äúmust have‚Äù gear is my MP3 player, so essential that I carry a spare one.
My biggest fear is the crocodiles sneaking out of Scottish lochs and picking off the slow old bloke at the back!

: For bags I'm using a merry mix of Ortlieb, Agu and Restrap. I recently swapped my Seat Pack for the Tailfin alu setup for easier entrance and packability. I'm carrying water in a Camelbak Chase bike vest (1,5l). The downtube bidon holds most of my tools.

body:

Bikes of Trans Pyrenees Race 2023
30 September, 2023
This weekend, the 2023 cohort of the TPR will make their way from the shores of the Atlantic in Southwest France, over the Pyreneen watershed three times before reaching the Costa Brava on the Mediterranean and turning round to return to Saint-Jean-de-Luz again. Riders need to route themselves between five control points and a handful of mandatory parcours, but the roads, tracks and paths between are theirs to choose.
For 2023, the race will be approximately 200km longer than 2022, totalling ~1,700km, but has an additional 10,000m of climbing amounting to ~40,000m. For the more adventurous souls, there are a handful of hiking trails that can be used to link up the mandatory sections. This makes this year‚Äôs edition hillier than ever and combined with the potential hike-a-bikes, the eternal dilemma of balancing adequate equipment and weight will be more critical than ever. As Lost Dot claim, this certainly is "one for the grimpeurs".
The race starts at 06:00 (CEST) from Saint-Jean-de-Luz in France's Basque country, don't miss a beat by following veteran racer David Sherrington's

body:

Fara Bikes Of... Badlands 2023
3 September, 2023
Covered By: Fara Cycling
To celebrate our new relationship with Fara Cycling, we‚Äôre launching a special edition of Bikes Of‚Ä¶ exploring the Fara athletes‚Äô Fara F/Gravel bikes ready to tackle Badlands. Fara Cycling is an independent maker of premium bikes based in Norway. With ex-pro Jeff Webb at the helm, Fara has leant into the concept of riding further without compromising on performance. Take a look at our lineup of Fara F/ Gravel bikes to learn more.
Gereon Tewes, Cap 70, Amsterdam
You may know Gereon from his recent result as first pair at TCRNo9. Him and his partner, Sherry, finished top 20 in the Transcontinental Race this year, something very rare in such an intense race. He now finds himself finally on social media and ready to shred at Badlands. For the ride he‚Äôs got a new Fara F/Gravel to ride.
Bike
: Fara F/Gravel - Size 59
Groupset
: Shimano GRX 1x Mechanical
Wheels
: DT Swiss with Schwalbe 45mm G-One RS tyres
Finishing Kit
: Red Shift suspension seatpost setup, Garmin Rally pedals, Specialized 3D printed Power saddle, Vision Aerobars
Packs
: Apidura Backcountry Full Frame Pack, Apidura Top Tube Pack, Apidura Hydration Vest
Accessories
: Supernova Lights
Kit
: Velocio
Simen Nordahl Svendsen, Cap 6, Mj√∏ndalen, Norway
Simen is a long-time cyclist and now an elite gravel racer. After starting to cycle in his late teens he raced on the road at the elite level until making the switch to gravel. He started his Gravelleur season last year finding himself at the front of most races, he decided to make the switch permanent in 2023. Now, he‚Äôs taking the step into ultra-racing with Fara to tackle Badlands 2023.
Bike
: Fara F/Gravel
Groupset
: SRAM Red 1x 42x10-44
Wheels
: Fulcrum Carbon wheelset, Schwalbe G-One Bite 50mm at around 25psi.
Finishing Kit
:Fara integrated cockpit
Packs
: Fara integrated frame bag, 7l Saddle pack for gear.
Accessories
: Front and rear light as well as helmet lights, 3x bottle cages and a Camelbak with 1.5l, powerbank to keep lights and navigation running, Wahoo Roam for navigation.
Jeff Webb, Cap 183, Oslo, Norway
Jeff is an ex-pro racer who started off his own premium bike brand, Fara Cycling. His experience in the pro world was complemented by his extensive experience in ultra-cycling, finishing races like Badlands, the Italy Divide and Bikingman. The Canadian native now lives and trains in Norway after his career in pro-cycling and pro-sports photography as he runs Fara.
Bike
: Fara F/Gravel, riding a larger 56 from his 53 to accommodate more packs and increase the wheelbase, RockShox Rudy on the front to make descents more fun and help with hand issues.
Groupset
: SRAM Force 1x 38x10-44
Wheels
: Fulcrum Rapid Red Carbon Wheels with Pirelli Gravel M 45mm
Finishing Kit
: Fara Integrated Handlebars with attachment points for ControlTech Aerobars, Crank Brothers Candy Pedals.
Packs
: weather dependent saddle pack (if it‚Äôs fine it‚Äôll be left at home), half length top tube pack, handlebar pack that converts to hip pack in the front for bars and gels.
Accessories
: Exposure lights mounted on lower GPS mount, Exposure Diablo on the helmet, Wahoo Roam for navigation, 2 bottles and a hydration vest.
Marie Rydne, Cap 233, Gothenburg, Sweden
Marie is the winner of the 2023 Fara giveaway with Fulcrum. She's an experienced gravel rider and cyclist racing TTTs and plenty of other events, she even holds the record for riding across Sweden. Badlands will be her first attempt at ultra-distance cycling and she is certainly one to watch.
Bike
: Fara F/Gravel size 53
Groupset
: Campagnolo Ekar 13 speed
Wheels
: Fulcrum Carbon Wheelset, Schwalbe G-One Bite 50mm
Finishing Kit
: Gravel drop bars
Packs
: Fara integrated frame bag, Restrap top tube pack, Apidura cockpit pouch.
Accessories
: Gaciron Lights, GoPro and mounts
Kit
: Velocio

Bikes of At Last Lost 2023
31 August, 2023
If you don't know where you're going, how do you know what to pack? The 15 intrepid riders of this inaugural free-route race with unreleased checkpoints have equipped themselves to truly head into the unknown around the North of Portugal.
The race starts in the port town of Aviero and the first CP will be released a few hours before the the start. Each rider's route between the CPs is theirs to design and their bike choice will play a large part in the possible route options; they'll move faster on a road bike but a gravel or MTB will open up many shortcuts.

body:

Bikes of Utrecht Ultra 2023
5 August, 2023
This epic ride combines the thrill of exploration with the challenge of endurance. Starting in Utrecht, we‚Äôll head south on a set route into beautiful Belgium, and then tackle three checkpoints and parcours in the stunning Belgian Ardennes and Germany's Eifel region.
The journey ends back in Utrecht, where memories and miles meet.
Given the road terrain and relatively flat nature of the course, this feature is packed with some of the fastest setups we‚Äôve ever seen. Blink and you‚Äôll miss them!
Follow along
with expert commentator Julia Freeman to discover who is the first to return to Utrecht and the many tales from the road along the way.
Ingrida Kazakeviciute
Name
: Ingrida Kazakeviciute
Age
: 26
Cap number
: 94
Location
: Amsterdam, Netherlands

: Cannondale SuperSix EVO 2021 Rapha edition. Shimano Ultegra 12sp Di2, Hollowgram 35 wheels, Hollowgram Si cockpit.

Key items of kit
: Waterproof Apidura bags with my sleeping kit in the back and mechanical + charging items in the frame bag. I also carry a small Apidura Musette, just in case I need it. The Restrap Top Tube Bag will be the place for all the snacks. I think they are necessary for the trip :). 38mm Ritchey Evocurve Handlebar Narrow for fast but comfy handling with 3mm bar tape and gel pads. Aerobars are a Profile Design/3T mashup. 70mm risers
Wahoo Elemnt Bold. Exposure Lights Strada Frontlight.
Key items of kit
: I will carry all that is needed in a collection of well trusted Alpkit Bags and one Custom Framebag Prototype that has some great tweaks. I will also ride with a USWE Backpack for extra Water and Food Capacity to go further without stopping.
The Aerobar Setup with 70mm is all about comfort to get the most km out of it, while still giving a huge speed boost.
The Exposure Lights front light is one of my favorite pieces of equipment. The way you can tweak the runtime is genius.

Bikes Of The Great British Divide 2023
2 August, 2023
The Great British Divide is one of the longest off-road races on the UK race scenes. Traversing the UK over 2000km, this race is in its third year and shows no sign of slowing down.
Follow the commentary here.
Craig Black
Name
: Craig Black
Age
: 52
Location
: Newport on Tay
Bike
: 2015 Merida Big 9 - 1000. Shimano XT Di2 with XT brakes. Scribe All Mountain Carbon Wheelset with Maxxis Ardent tubeless tyres.  Magic shine front and rear lights and an ¬£8 saddle off Ali Express.
Key items of kit
: Bags are a mix of Blackburn and Restrap with a Restrap musette for resupply. Paria gravel kit with loads of pockets in jersey and shorts.  Garmin 1040 solar and Wahoo Roam for backup will take care of navigation.  Couple of 20000mah power banks will hopefully keep everything going for a while.  4L Cranktank inspired by Joe Nation for all my hydration goodness.

Bikes of Log Driver's Waltz 2023
28 July, 2023
Bikes of Log Driver's Waltz Canada, a gravel grinding tour of Southern Quebec. Riders have 805km to cover, with some ready for speed and others for an adventure check out this varied array of bikes!
Follow along here.
Andrew Woodside
Name
: Andrew Woodside
Age
: 37
Location
: Montr√©al
Bike
: 2018 Kona Sutra TA
Key items of kit
: Surly Moloko bars, Ergon grips and saddle, Ortleib, Topeak and Atwater bags, Deore 3x drivetrain with 26/36/48 chainrings and a good old 11-34 cassette
Mitchell Sinclair
Name
: Mitchell Sinclair
Age
: 28
Location
: Ottawa
Bike
: 2022 Trek Checkpoint SL5. 2X GRX drivetrain, running 44mm Rene Herse Snoqualmie Pass tires.
Key items of kit
: I am using a combination of Apidura (front) and Road Runner (saddle/frame) bags. I will be using a Big Agnes Fly Creek HV UL2 tent with a MEC 0 degree bag and Klymit Inertia Ozone sleeping pad.  I will be using a NiteRider 1200 Boost front light, NiteRider rear light, and a backup headlamp. Cook kit will include MSR Pocket Rocket and lots of oatmeal.

Age

Location

Bike

32x17 gear ratio most likely.
Key items of kit

Taking a bivy, rain jacket, down jacket and down pants in the frame bag.

Touch points include an alloy Jones Loop bar, Ergon SM-Pro saddle and MKS-Always, EZ Superior pedals (removable without tools for long hike-a-bikes).
Key items of kit
: The J-Paks frame bag and SnakPak are superb, -up to 4 liters of water in the frame bag and some food. A BikepackersFoundry  bottle-cradle also occupies the top tube. Camp (Locus Gear shelter) is in the front drybag; clothes-rain gear ride atop a Lynskey  Ti rear rack.  Tools are in a Tailfin bag beneath the downtube. Electronics are in a Banana Hammock from Broadfork Bags: Garmin Edge 1040 for navigation and a Son dynamo connects to a kLITE "USB always-on" wire loom.  Extra snacks, bug dope... are in the stem bags (by Ghost Cat Bags).

Deore 160mm front and v-brake rear. 26" 36h Sun Rims Rhyno Lites laced to a front SP dynamo and a Deore rear. The tires are Rene Herse Humptulips Ridge 26 x 2.3, with Stans sealants and Stans schrader tubeless valves. Bassi Bobby bar, Redshift QR aerobars, Redshift Race suspension seatpost, Specialized Power saddle, Wolf Tooth Fat Paw grips, and XT pedals.

: Road Runner Buoy Bag with sleep kit in the rear (OR Helium bivvy, McKinley sleeping pad, SOL XL emergency blanket, and a sleeping bag liner all rolled into one) and night clothes in the front. EVOC top tube bag with pharmacy and toiletries, and Revalte Design feedbag for snacking. Customized large Blackburn Outpost Elite frame bag with tools and pump on the bottom and race fuel, first-aid kit, 1L Katadyn Befree, Hiplok, battery bank, charging cables and Muc-Off dry shower up top. For charging and lights, I have a new Sinewave Beacon 2 upfront hooked up to my dynamo. For hydration, I have two 750ml Camelback bottles on the fork and a hydration bladder in my vest
Jen Adams

: 60
Location

Key items of kit
: BAGS: Custom made with Ecopack EPX 200 by the Log Driver‚Äôs Waltz (i.e. Eric and me) mini-pannier saddle bags, trunk bag, jerry can, front roll, feed bag and glasses holster. My Topeak gas tank has suffered modification by a pesky red squirrel but with a new zipper thanks to Refasten.ca is still functioning.
GEAR HIGHLIGHTS: Sleep system of a Tyvek bivy, Thermarest Neoair Xlite, and down jacket. Navigating by Wahoo Bolt with phone as backup.

Name
: Christina Vietinghoff
Location
: Montr√©al, Qu√©bec

But to my surprise, I really fell in love with this bike even though it has some quirks like weirdly placed braze-ons. I inherited these tires from a friend and splurged on the aerobars last year in preparation for another ultra race.
Key items of kit
: I have a Brooks Cambium saddle on this bike that I bought in Whitehorse in 2017. I ended up riding that Brooks Cambium saddle all the way to Peru, it's very worn and it got scrapped on the ceiling of an airport parking lot when I forgot it was on the roof of my car, but I'm more comfortable on that saddle than on my feet.

Lots of room for food. About 3 liters of water. Gorilla tape and super glue gel. Dynamo hub, cache battery, Garmin, spot, cables that hopefully work, and a phone who hates me for riding through too many gritty sandy rainstorms.

Key items of kit

Everything held together with zipties and electrical tape.
Eric Betteridge
Name
: Eric Betteridge
Age
: 61
Location
: Ottawa, Canada
Bike
: Panorama Cycles Taiga EXP- "Blake". The cockpit of Ritchey Venturemax bars and Redshift top grips came over "holus bolus" from my old bike making the EXP feel like home; but better! The wheels by Woven Precision are awesome to climb with and solid on the descents. If it's all psychological, that's ok! As for tires I went with 2.1" rather than 2.25" Mezcals this time mainly because of availability, but they are feeling good and it is the size of tire I have used on three previous LDW trips. What really sets this bike apart for me is the gearing: 1x12, 10-52 on the rear and 34T on the front gives me a lower climbing gear than I have used in the past. Climbing McCloskey's has always been challenge with a load, so we'll see how it goes.  Shifting and braking is all cable actuated. The Ratio Technology shifting in the Rival lever is really crisp. My seat is a relatively inexpensive Giant Approach and is mounted on a carbon seat post.
Key items of kit
: This is a new bike for me but the custom home sewn bags with the exception of the seatbag are the same as I used on the Tour Divide and the 2022 LDW Grand Depart. Lighting is rechargeable O-light on the front and a Lezyne rear as I don't intend to ride all night!

The Three Peaks Bike Race is one for the Grimpeurs. Climbing is in its DNA and our riders have to find the perfect balance between weight and comfort. See how they went.
Follow the race
here
.

Location
: Paris, France
Bike
: Vitus Zenium Road
Key items of kit
: Miss Grape bags, DHB equipment, Northwave shoes for my feet, and Hutchinson Sector 32 for bike's feet. Sinewave front light, Shimano Ultegra, hydraulic brakes, White Industry 50/32 crankset, White Industry rear hub, Dynamo Son 28 front hub, DT Swiss RR421 rims, Sinewave front light, Thomson X2 stem, Thomson Masterpiece seatpost, Ergon ST ProWomen saddle and 3T Ultimate Performance Tbars.
Miss Grape bags. Saddle bag for sleeping gear from Sea to Summit, warm clothes and extra kit from DHB, top tube bag for toiletry, food pouch for food (obviously) and frame bag for tools. I always carry a musette, it is like a large pocket to carry more food, it becomes a pillow at night, it comes handy in any circumstances.
Fatih Eroglu
Name
: Fatih Eroglu
Age
: 39
Location
: L√∂rrach, Germany
Bike
: Open U.P. with Easton Parts (Wheels, Seatpost, Crank, Handlebar), SQLab saddle. Hub Dynamos from "Son". Total weight bikepacking setup: ~17kg.
Key items of kit
: First time, I am using a hub dynamo to be more flexible and independent.
Power charging during the day and no light issues during the night.
My sleep system is very simple: sleeping bag and sleeping pad -> find a dry place during the ride to have some rest.
My mental trick: A choclate as an reward after each achievement of a long climb.
Jimmy Ashby
Name

Age

Cap number

Key items of kit
: My sleeping bag. I went a trip to Denmark without it and froze every night. Never again, im looking forward to plenty of warm sleeps, hopefully! I will also take a small Vaude rucksack for quck access to a light jacket, gloves and food.

Location

: I am riding a Specialized Roubaix with Pancho Rush wheels equipped with Continental GP 5000 32mm tires. The groupset is Di2 and with some dubious cabling and junction box placement I connected aero bar shifters on the Profile Design Subsonic Race clip-on aerobars. Gearing is 11-34 in the back and 50-34 in the front.
Key items of kit
: My Apidura 0.8l food pouch ensures a steady supply of Haribo is always at hand. The Apidura Racing Top Tube Pack Long houses additional snacks, whereas the Apidura Frame Bag contains all the electronics, tools and so on. The saddle bag is an Ortlieb Seat Pack 11l where i put my spare clothes and my sleeping setup: Sea to Summit Spark Zero and a Thermarest Uberlight. My main light is a Supernova M99 mini pro B54. As I am riding without a dynamo hub I bring a 20k mAh powerbank and my secondary light (Ravmen PR16000) is also an emergency powerbank. Rear light is a Garmin Varia which I also intend to use at daytime for busy roads.

Bikes of Pan Celtic Race 2023
3 July, 2023
For the first time in the race's history, riders will bridge The Channel and ferry across from the start in the Celtic nation of Brittany, France to Great Britain before a run along the rolling hills of Southern England and over the Severn Bridge into the second Celtic nation on route. Once in Wales, riders will head north with some dog legs along the way and almost traverse the length of the country to the finish and spiritual home of the race in Llandudno.
The weather of the Celtic nations is at the mercy of the gods and their fickle whims. Each edition has faced its own elemental conditions from biblical rain to a heatwave in Ireland. While there are no high mountains on the route, riders will cross a large body of land and water, and need to be prepared for their varying challenges.
