Bikes of Bright Midnight 2023
26 June, 2023
Packing for an inaugural race brings its unique challenges when riders know so little about the conditions they'll face over the coming 1,000km. Into the unknown they go!
From the mountain city of Tolga, riders head westward into the Norwegian highlands, to the coast and back again. This new route links endless gravel roads amongst farmland of the highlands before reaching the iconic fjords on Norway's west coast before heading inland again back to Tolga with a few mountains in between.
At this latitude there are so few hours of darkness, riders can be sure they'll not need too many lights but they'll be challenged in other ways along the route. Norway is a relatively new and untravelled area for bikepacking races so don't miss a beat and follow along with the

: It began life as a lockdown project to build a mid-range bike on an entry level budget - ¬£500 all in. It‚Äôs a mix of parts from other bikes I‚Äôve worked on, eBay, and a handful of new bits. Since then its evolved a little as I‚Äôve ridden it more and the spec is now as follows. It‚Äôs a real mish-mash, but it all works great:
2015 Genesis Volant Frame & forks
Miche Long drop calliper brakes
Shimano 105 11 speed shifters
Shimano 105 Front Mech
Shimano GRX Rear Mech
Sram Rival 50-34T Chainset
Sunrace 12-40T Cassette

Restrap Race Stem Bag
Roswheel Road 3.5l Frame Bag
Key Items of Kit:
All my interesting bits of kit are related to my #plasticfreeultra attempt. Number 1 is my enamel mug! It's the perfect size for a petrol station coffee. Second is my ‚ÄúFull Windsor‚Äù titanium multitool/spork. Critical for opening (and eating!) cans of rice pudding - a vital part of my plastic-free nutrition strategy. Nutrition wise I‚Äôve spent a bunch of time working out what I can buy on the road, and what I can carry that will have minimal impact. The main things I‚Äôll have with me from the outset are: a bunch Outdoor Provisions energy bars; Luchos DIllitos energy cubes; loose jelly beans purchased from local sweet shop; and a huge back of DIY trail mix from local refill store.
And an honourable mention goes to the two other things I couldn‚Äôt live without: hayfever tablets, and my Bontrager Biodynamic insoles. One to keep the allergies in check, and the other to keep the hot-foot at bay.

Bikes of Race Around the Netherlands GX 2023
16 June, 2023
For the first time the Race Around the Netherlands will hit the gravel tracks. A distance of 1,230km of racing with a mere 3,220m of climbing is deceptive; what doesn't go up, can't come down and therefore gets no rest. Riders will consistently be pushing the pedals as there are no easy kilometres in this race.
Weight becomes less of an issue with these statistics, but it does mean aerodynamics are evermore important. Staying true to its nature with flat fast sections, this time riders will just need a little more tyre to tackle this gravel race.
Follow along with commentary veteran, Julia Freeman's,
commentary here

Bikes of Taunus Bikepacking No. 6
9 June, 2023
This 1,000km challenging route has been coined ‚ÄúJesko‚Äôs rollercoaster‚Äù as the Taunus hills, which are not high mountains, are full of relentless up and down which are more than enough to wear bikes and riders out.
Riders will pass over a wild mix of gravel roads, asphalt lanes, cobblestone alleys and forest trails. They will be treated to a tour of this region‚Äôs history including remains of the Roman empire‚Äôs last frontier, medieval towns, deserted army depots and defunct slate mines.

Bikes of the TransAtlantic Way 2023
9 June, 2023
This fixed route road race along the Wild Atlantic Way on the west coast of Ireland returns for 2023. An original of the UK's bikepacking scene, the TAW is well known for its ferry crossings, out-and-back peninsulas and Irish charm.
Take a look below to see how riders have equipped themselves for this lap of Ireland's rugged west coast with plenty of climbing, inclement weather and mandatory rest periods.
You can follow along with the race commentary
here
.

title: Bikes of Blaenau 600 2023
body:
DotWatcher.cc
Event Commentary
Results
Event Calendar
Features
About Us
Bikes of Blaenau 600 2023
8 June, 2023
A mixed terrain adventure in the Welsh uplands along the land's finest off-road sewn together with characteristically hilly tarmac, including the Brecons, Berwyns, Black Mountains, Cambrians and Snowdonia.
You can follow along with the race commentary
here
Jason Oliver
Name
: Jason Oliver
Age
: 49
Location
: Hereford
Bike
: Kinesis Tripster ATR Ti. GRX 810 mechanical. Mason x Hunt 650b alloy buttered up to Terravail Cannonball 650b x 47mm. Praxis carbon 1x crankset setup with 34t x 11-42. Hope carbon post and Richey wcs finishing kit.
Key items of kit
: Sleep system is Rab neutrino 200, Exped Synmat, Nemo Dragonfly bikepacking tent.
Apidura expedition bags, with Topeka bar bag for ultimate snack carriage.
James Griffiths (Giff)
Name
: James Griffiths (Giff)
Age
: 50
Location
: Stottesdon, South Shropshire
Bike
: Custom Built TORUS Titanium CX/Gravel Frame designed by Andy Jones of Clee Cycles here in South Shropshire, with Columbus Carbon Forks.
Custom built wheels with Hope Pro RS4 Hubs, Stans Grail Rims, Sapim CX Ray Aero Spokes and running tubeless 2.1inch Schwalbe Thunder Burt Tyres.
Shimano GRX Rear Derailleur and Shifters, XT Cranks, 42-11 XT Cassette and a Single 36t AbsoluteBlack oval chainring.
Exposure Toro and Joystick Lights.
Key items of kit
: Alpkit Framebag combined with Topeak Front Loader and Rear Loader Bags.
Camelback Chase bike vest for water and extra carrying space.
Alpkit Hunka Bivvy Bag along with a 2 season sleeping bag and lightweight mat.
Smidge Midge-Proof Headnet for the inevitable midges!
Pair of Garmin Edge 530s.
Anker Power Bank to keep things charged.
First major ride of this type so will be interesting to see how it goes!
Lee Endres
Name
: Lee Endres
Age
: 36
Location
: London
Bike
: Open WI.DE
Key items of kit
: Pirelli cinturato 45 M for th√© varied terrain. I‚Äôve also fitted a smaller/oval chainring for the frequent climbs. I‚Äôll be using tailfin bags and a warm sleeping bag - there‚Äôs nothing worse than being cold at the end of the long day on the bike!

: Specialized Chisel

Garmin eTrex for navigation, Exposure lights, Specialized clothing and kit.

Key items of kit
: I'm using a mish-mash of Bags from Alpkit, Restrap and Planet X. Sleeping kit is a cheap bivvy bag from Mountain Warehouse that was half price, a Sea2Summit Ultralight Mat, OEX Thermal Liner and an inflatable pillow. My lucky item is numerous bags of Haribo Tangfastics.
Mike Jacklin

: 42

: 20

Age
: 35

: 19

Hoops are wrapped in some Halo rubber too, a GXR on the rear and a GXC on the front, grippy and fast. 47mm and 650b is new for me with this bike, and excited to get rolling loose and throw up some dust through Wales.

Lights from Endura. In my tool keg, the Dyna plug is probably the most likely bit of kit to be used. I'm aiming to ride single use plastic free, so home made goodies will be filling my food bags.

DT Swiss wheels

title: Bikes of Trans Balkans Race 2023
body:
DotWatcher.cc
Event Commentary
Results
Event Calendar
Features
About Us
Bikes of Trans Balkans Race 2023
1 June, 2023
The bikes of the 2023 Trans Balkans Race. This 1350km race with 27,000m of ascent will see riders tackling Balkan gravel with a 98% rideability. Will riders favour light and fast or savour the journey?
Follow along
here
.
Askan von Schirnding
Name
: Askan von Schirnding
Age
: 29
Cap number
: 95
Location
: Gernany
Bike
: Rose Backroad
Key items of kit
: Dynamo, Bottle under aerobars.
Gabi Winck
Name
: Gabi Winck
Age
: 60
Cap number
: 128
Location
: Brixen, South Tyrol, Italy
Bike
: Trek Procaliber 9.8, Carbon, IsoSpeed, Fork: Fox Performance 32, Boost110; Retractable seatpost: Fox Racing Transfer SL Factory; Crank: e*thirteen TRS Race Carbon, 30T; Cassette: Shimano XT M8100, 9-50, 12-speed; Brakes: Shimano Deore XT M8100 hydraulic disc; Bontrager RSL Integrated handlebar; Wheel front: XM 421 - DT Swiss, Hub Dynamo: SON 28; Wheel rear: Bontrager Kovee Elite 30 Carbon, Tubeless Ready; Tyre: Vittoria mezcal III 29‚Äô‚Äôx 2,25‚Äô‚Äô; Saddle: ISM PL1.; Syntace Aerobar.
Key items of kit
: BAGS:
I hope that in the end I don't carry too many things to in the Tailfin AeroPack Carbon, 1 Tailfin mini pannier, Apidura Expedition handlebar pack & Apidura expedition accessory pocket, Apidura packable backpack; Revelate Designs Gas Tank, Revelate Designs Mountain Feedbag Handlebar Bag; Apidura racing hydration vest. Not in the picture: Two Tailfin Cargo Cages mounted on the suspension fork - for additional water bottles
GEAR HIGHLIGHTS:
Front light is a SON Edelux II powered by a Son 28 dynamo and on my helmet: Lupine Piko; rear lights are Bontrager flare RT and Lupine Rotlicht Max LED. Battery chargers are NC-17, Connect APPCON 3000; mini pump: Lezyne Micro Floor Drive.
I also hope that I find my way safely north with my Garmin Edge 1040. I want to dream for a few (or more?) hours in my tent: Nordisk ‚Äì Lofoten2, on my Therma-a-Rest NeoAir mat and my thin sleeping bag: Yeti/ Passion One. And last but not least that my seat bones are not too strained on my saddle ISM PL 1.1 in my beloved cycling shorts Skinfit tri shorts and Assos half shorts.
As always- no matter about the weight: As my lucky item I absolutely have to bring my little scuffed white BEAR with me, who accompanied me on the Atlas Mountain Race, GBDuro, NorthCape4000 and Three Peaks Bike Races, among others.
Nicky Shaw
Name
: Nicky Shaw
Age
: 33
Cap number
: 81
Location
: Harrogate, UK
Bike
: Trek Procaliber 9.6
Key items of kit
: - Apidura Backcountry bag setup with Albion kit, tailored to the mountains and remoteness with max water capacity of 4L.
Exposure Maxx-D Front light and Lezyne Macro Drive 1300 as back up.
Alpkit Numo mat, Alpkit Hunka Bivvy and RAB solar 1 sleeping bag.
Wahoo Roam to guide the way.
Jacques Brown
Name
: Jacques Brown
Age
: 50
Cap number
: 14
Location
: Dubai, United Arab Emirates
Bike
: My bike of choice is the Sunpeed Rock which is a carbon fibre frame with a weight of 11.5kg. The bike comes with a standard 1x12 drivetrain and a 34T chainring. I've added pedals which feature both a clipless side and a platform side giving me the option to clip in or ride trickier sections using the  platform side. I initially put a thin carbon fibre seat on but that didn't withstand riding on rough terrain so moved back to a more solid plastic cast seat. Gone through four different options before settling on the right one for me. (Seat choice is so important!!!) Front tubeless tire is the Vittoria Barzo and rear is Mitas Kratos.
Key items of kit
: BAGS: I've gone for the M-Wave frame bag and seat pack (11L). It's a tight squeeze for everything I'm packing but I've managed to get everything in, including a small gas cooker and pot set. Rock Bros top tube bag for my spare tube, chain and tools. On the handlebars I've put a basket with a small cooler bag with two compartments. One to keep drinks cold and the other for food. Packing enough liquids is my primary concern, so I'll be carrying roughly 8L of liquids in total spread out between my 3L Camelpac, a custom bottle carrier on the frame, the cooler and frame bag.
GEAR HIGHLIGHTS: For navigation I've gone with the Wahoo Elemnt V2. For power I've chosen a lite foldable solar panel and power bank. So solar by day and power bank by night. All my other gear is pretty much standard gear for races like this but I have added a rain poncho as I want to stay as dry as possible and the extra layer over my waterproofs will ensure this. It's also great to put over my tent (presumably 100% waterproof) or create shade where none can be found. Adding the gas cooker and pot set has been a huge internal debate but it's being packed in. A warm soup or coffee, or hot meal when I'm cold, wet and out in the middle of nowhere hundreds of km's from any resupply, will keep me sane.

Bikes of Mittelgebirge Classique 2023
19 May, 2023
Back for its second edition, the 158 riders of the MittelgebirgeClassique will cross from Germany to France and back, tackling a vertiginous 40 mountain passes in 1,100km of the middle mountains (Mittelgebirge) ranges including the Palatinate Forest, Black Forest and Vosges.
In a race with this much climbing, see how riders have kept their kit lists as minimal as possible, or not.
You can follow along with the race once it starts on Sunday 21st May at our
commentary here
.
Karsten Morisse

Bike

Key items of kit
: Apidura packs.
Gerhard Kohl
Name
: Gerhard Kohl
Age
: 56
Cap number
: 41
Location
: Neunkirchen am Brand, Germany
Bike
: My trusted bespoked steel frame Randonneur from Meerglas inspired by the great french randonneur bicycles and proven in many Brevets.
My transmission is 11sp with down tube shifters, a 42/26 combo at the front and a 11-36 cassette at the rear wheel. I'm a slow guy on the bike and will need any help from a low gear transmission on the hills.
Wheels are 650B Pacenti rims with a SON dynamo hub at the front, and a White Industry hub at the rear. 42mm Rene Herse EL tires with tubes. Front light is an SON Edelux II and the rear light is from Compass, all wired internally and with an steerer cap switch for easy on/off switching. A Lupine Rotlicht and an Exposure Lights Diablo as backup and for fast descents during the nights. Fenders from Honjo and center pull brakes from Compass. The front and saddle bags are from Gilles Berthoud. The Gilles Berthoud leather saddle and a Grand Bois Randonneur drop bar with arm rests are my comfort warranty.
Key items of kit
: I travel as light as possible, since my loved steel bike is heavy enough. And getting older, I appreciate the comfort of a dry bed and a warm shower, therefore I will look out every day for a stay at a local boarding house and skip carrying a sleeping bag. All stuff must fit into the front and saddle bag. A musette bag for extra food is used only when really necessary.
I don't want to mess around with charging my equipment by hunting down power outlets and being as independent as possible, therefore the most important key item is my SON dynamo combined with a "Forumslader". It will power everything: My lights, my Wahoo Bolt and if needed my phone. And the 3rd empty bottle cage for the occasional coke to carry me through the dark hours.

Bikes of Seven Serpents 2023
10 May, 2023
Back for its second edition, 172 riders will tackle this 850km set route passing through seven checkpoints across Slovenia, Croatia and Italy from mountain tops to marina towns. An off-road bonanza on some of Southern Europe's lesser ridden gravel and secondary roads from long-time racer Bruno Ferraro makes for excellent dotwatching.
It's a
mostly
fast rolling course with great landscape diversity along the Adriatic Coast, the Dinaric Alps and finally the Mediterranean. You can follow along with the race at our commentary
here
.

: 3
Location
: Zwolle, The Netherlands
Bike
: Van Nicholas Rowtag (Ti) with GRX Di2. Cogs: 11 speed with front: 48 & 31T and rear 11-34. Fenders to keep me dry, clean and happy: SKS Bluemels Primus Aerobar: Deda Parabolica Uno with Riser Kit (45mm). Tyres are Schwalbe One TLE 700x28c. Front wheel is a carbon custom build, unbranded with Son 28 Dynamo Hub and rear wheel is Zipp 303 Firecrest. Electronics are Supernova E3 Pro head and tail light. NC-17 Appcon 3000 USB charger and back-up lights from CatEye Volt 400/800 to see some more in the pitchdark descents.
Key items of kit
: Framebag: Blackburn Outpost Elite and Tailfin Aeropack with Tailfin Cage pack holding down jacket and rain jacket still to decide which one and other stuff to keep warm and freshen up.. Apidura Backcountry Food Pouches on both sides and 2.5L in water bottles.
I will bring some winter gloves (GripGrab Ride Waterproof) and less thick for less worse weather. Rain tight overshoes and thick ones to keep feet warm.
Because of the weather I am for hotels and lodges, sleeping outside doesn't seem attractive this early in the year.
Gary Short
Name
: Gary Short
Age
: 41
Cap number
: 13
Location
: Athens, Greece
Bike
: Peugeot PH10 1986 Carbolite steel frameset
Donhou Cycles custom fork
Shimano Tiagra 10 speed (50-34 crankset, 11-33 cassette) - the true group of the people
Scribe FW, DT Swiss R551 laced to scribe hub.
Schwalbe One tubeless 700x28c
Shimano PD-EH500 dual platform pedals
Specialized Romin Evo 142mm saddle
This steel beast maybe heavy but it laps up the KMs in a way only classic steel can, springy and spritly but supple enough to absorb road chatter coupled with the large tubeless tyres its set for pretty much anything the parcour throws at us

: Camelchops -
Hump top tube bag - electronics
Blimp 2.0 handle bar bag, mounted on aero bars - food and supplements

Garmin Edge 830 bike computer

https://youtu.be/kho7y-0giNE

Myog Framebag for clothes like my myog 78g DCF rain jacket, down jacket, arm warmers, leg warmers etc.
TT bag by my friend Max for snacks and a bunch of electronics
Small tool bag for spare tubes and tools
Clip on aerobars
I'm not sure if this will be comfortable enough but I wanted to keep the bike as close to it's "normal" condition as possible.

Cap number

Sinewave Beacon for light and charging duties combined with a Supernova rear light. A mix of mostly Restrap bags with an old Revelate Pika seat bag. For this race going to add a trail running race vest to carry some more food for a French Easter weekend with possibly very little shops open....
Key items of kit

-for charching: Busch & M√ºller USB-Werk
-main lights: Supernova E3 Tripple front light, Son rear light
-extra lights: Lezyne 115 pro (front), Lezyne stripe pro 300 (rear)
-navigation: Garmin 1040 and as backup: Poco M3

Bikes of GranGuanche Audax Gravel 2023
18 March, 2023
The 700km route goes by fast gravel roads and secondary paved roads while avoiding rocky singletrack or sandy sections. It's open to any kind of bike, but the organizers recommend gravel bikes with low gearing and a minimum of 40mm tires. You will see from the submissions that the balance between speed, weight and comfort has resulted in a range of bikes with tyre choice being of particular interest and importance. Also considering the lack of natural water sources on the islands, the riders will have to rely on establishments and have the capacity to carry resources over distance.

Bikes of Race around Rwanda 2023
4 February, 2023
A 1,000km route around the Land of a Thousand Hills demands a minimal kit list that's equipped enough to face any of the Rwandan mechanical mishaps. The gravel roads have claimed many sets of brake pads over the years, and no doubt will claim more in the third edition, however, the riders shy of the rough stuff will be pleased to know a handful of the off-road sections have been improved, and even tarmaced.
A very real challenge in Rwanda is the lack of availability of wild camping spots; this densely populated nation has made good use of the fertile land which leaves very little opportunity to throw down a bivvy. Fortunately, hotels and other accommodation is easy to come by, if not harder to leave than a bivvy! Hamlets and villages can be found at regular intervals so that finding food and water doesn‚Äôt pose too much of a challenge.
Follow along
with veterans Rob Gardiner and Niel Copeland who will be adding some context to the dots and plenty of route and racing knowledge. Racers will be hoping for dry weather, but we won't be! Let the dotwatching commence.

Bikes of Across Andes 2022
22 November, 2022
Across Andes is back for its third edition and is an excellent way for us Europeans to close out our dotwatching calendar. Over 1,000km of riding in the high mountains of the Chilean Andes and its gravel roads demand for meticulous packing and an acute understanding of the upcoming challenges.
The race organiser's preference for a figure of eight route allows riders to experience the high and arid landscapes further north early on and later delight in the many contrasts of the southern loop: from the lush hillsides of the Villarrica National park for CP2 at Huila Huila to the flat coastal section before a final 300km run in to the finish.

Bikes of Two Volcano Sprint
11 October, 2022
Two Volcano Sprint has evolved into Europe's season closer, often attracting some of the finest names from the European circuit who attend with fatigue in their legs from a heavy race calendar. It's become an aggressively fast race with many riders pushing for one last win to set them up for a winter's training. It's also notorious for being an ultra-racer's dream with good Italian food never too far away.
For the first time since it's inception in 2019, the 2VS will be held as a free route incorperating 6 mandatory parcours. This could influence bike choices, with some opting for gravel shortcuts by choice, whilst all will have to face an off-road stretch of 14km at the end of parcours no.6. This year there will be a rider award for Most Adventurous, so this may also encourage some gravel setups and chunky tyres.
Have a browse below to see how each rider has equipped themselves for this Italian odyssey.

Bikes of Further Perseverance
25 August, 2022
Curating a kit list for a race with plentiful hike a bike, terrain ranging from tarmac to rock gardens, gradients steep enough to evoke vertigo and storms forecast is no small order. Racers have designed their kit list to be the ultimate compromise between weight and comfort, whilst also considering all the hiking they'll be doing and the rough terrain they'll be riding.
James Hayden described his winning setup in 2020 as light, fast and agile. He also said he didn't go to sleep, he went to race..

title: Bikes of GBDURO22
body:
DotWatcher.cc
Event Commentary
Results
Event Calendar
Features
About Us
Bikes of GBDURO22
8 August, 2022
GBDURO poses one of the greatest kit-list conundrums for riders; a 2,000km mixed-terrain route with three checkpoints where many riders will be waiting for a day or more and are disallowed from sleeping indoors, unlike previous years.
Riders equip themselves for both the riding and the resting, not to mention the notorious British weather. But with so much equipment to keep them comfortable at checkpoints, could this make them more likely to stop and slip into their tents mid-stage? Or will they push on for the relative comfort of the CPs?
Steve Wikeley
Name
: Steve Wikeley
Age
: 39
Location
: Devon, UK
Bike
: Mason Bokeh 1 with Hunt 650B Adventure SON dynamo wheels. Pushing the limits of the clearance with a 2.1 Teravail Sparwood Durable casing up front and a 47mm Teravail Cannonball durable casing both with Cushcore inserts - I'm hoping not to lose hours to ripped tyrewalls. Gearing is 1x 38t SRAM Force Chainset with mechanical GRX levers and mech with an XT 11-46 cassette. With a whopping big Gel Selle SMP TRK seat. And some crank brother egg beaters with extra float to help my ITB survive some extra miles ü§û
Human bike stand courtesy of my kids Caspian and Risu
Key items of kit
: Bags: By Apidura and Straight cut. Sleeping: Sea to Summit Spark I sleeping bag, Therm-a-Rest air mattress, Alpkit Kloke Bivy and the super comfy Sea to Summit down pillow. Lighting: Exposure: Sixpack, Diablo on my head, Tracers on back and hand full of back up lights. Tools: All the usual tools including a hooked needle, and a spare tyre as i'm totally freaked out about tyre issues after the Dales Divide. Electrics: 30,000 mAh across a few batteries charged by the dynamo. Biggest luxury: Mini massage gun to hopefully get my ITB injury through to JOG!
Zara Bellos
Name
: Zara Bellos
Age
: 29
Location
: Bristol, UK
Bike
: Stayer Groadinger UG
Key items of kit
: Omg everything! Wizard works frame and fork bags, tailfin rear bag, msr windburner stove, 3L bladder, bivvy bag, Albion cycling kit including my favourite gilet, rainbow handlebar tape, kLite Dynamo lights, my legs, tie dye socks, very cute mini toothbrush, a silly number of outdoor provisions bars, fun pink sunglasses. And the list could go on, every item of kit is key!!!!
Alan Goldsmith
Name
: Alan Goldsmith
Age
: 58
Location
: Wiltshire
Bike
: Ridley Kanzo Adventure. Good Year Connector 50mm tyres. Shimano GRX 46/30 x 11/42 gears. Tailfin rack, Aeropack and mini panier. Restrap top tube bag. Altura bar bag for tent and sleeping mat.
Key items of kit
: Alpkit Soloist tent. Rab Topbag sleeping bag. Exped Synmat sleeping mat. Garmin eTrex 20 for navigation. Columbia Outdry waterproof jacket and midge net for Scotland!
Molly Weaver
Name
: Molly Weaver
Age
: 28
Location
: Bristol, UK
Bike
: Salsa Warbird (Shimano GRX 800 1x), Stayer All-Road wheels and Pirelli Cinturato Gravel M tyres (700cx45).
Key items of kit
: On the bike I'm using an Ortlieb 9l handlebar pack and Ortlieb 11l seat-pack, plus I will be wearing a Camelbak Chase backpack for all the kit I want easy access to. My sleep system consists of an Outdoor Research hooped bivvy, Alpkit sleeping mat, down trousers, and a Patagonia Micro Puff jacket.. I decided not to go for a dynamo, instead opting for some long lasting and bright Fenix lights to illuminate the trail. For navigation I have the Garmin eTrex 32x, and the eTrex 22x as a backup.
Charles Aaron Beasley
Name
: Charles Aaron Beasley
Age
: 39
Location
: London, UK
Bike
: I'll be riding my Canyon Grizl SLX; AKA "DADDY". I've got some Apidura bags, some aerobars and a water bottle that I think I found at the arch? My dynamo front wheel was built with precision by the most excellent Max at the Cyclery Lewisham and all of the wiring was generously done by Alex from LVCC. I decided it was probably a good idea to be both as slow and as uncomfortable as possible, so I am running some 45s with almost no tread on them and I am bringing neither a tent nor a sleeping bag.
Key items of kit
: CVS 100+ face sunscreen.
Aandy Natarajan
Name
: Aandy Natarajan
Age
: 46
Location
: Sussex, UK
Bike
: Stayer Groadinger UG with Gravalloy wheelset. Hope crankset with 38t chainring and running Shimano Deore XT 11-46 cassette.
Key items of kit
: Custom bags made by Wizard Works. Tailfin rear rack. K-Lite dynamo lights running with Son dynamo hub. Teravail Cannonball tyres. Sleep kit consists of: Alpkit bivvy, Therm-a-Rest NeoAir mat, Alpkit quilt and a Decathlon inflatable pillow. My lucky item: moustache wax - my tache contains mystical special powers!
Nils Opgenorth
Name
: Nils Opgenorth
Age
: 26
Location
: Stuttgart, Germany
Bike
: I will be cruising with my cromoly butted Kona Sutra LTD, 1√ó11 SRAM RIVAL (10-42t) with 36T front chainring, WTB Riddler 700x45C (to which I will switch right before the race) and my comfy Brooks Cambium C15 saddle.
Key items of kit
: The bags are a mix of Ortlieb and Apidura. I will be sleeping in my Cloud Up 2 tent, which is packed with all my sleeping gear and some warmer clothes in the saddle bag. The frame bag carries spare parts, electronics and grocery shoppings on the way.

: 33
Location
: Leeds

: Milnes All Road C

Key items of kit

Key items of kit

Gabi Winck

: Gabi Winck
Age
: 59
Location
: Brixen, Italy
Bike

Key items of kit
: Tracking with a SPOT Gen 4. Front light is a SON Edelux II powered by a Son 28 dynamo and a backup Bontrager Ion 700 R, rear lights are Bontrager flare RT and Lupine Rotlicht Max LED. Battery chargers are NC-17, Connect APPCON 3000. I hope that in the end I don't carry too many things to John O‚ÄôGroats in the Tailfin AeroPack Carbon, Tailfin mini pannier, Revelate Designs Gas Tank, Cyclite handlebar roll bag, Miss Grape Bud, Apidura racing frame pack and Apidura packable backpack. I also hope that I find my way safely north with my Garmin Edge 1030 Plus. I want to dream for a few (or more?) hours in my Nordisk Lofoten tent, with my Therma-a-Rest NeoAir mat and Nordisk Yeti/Passion One sleeping bag... and last but not least that my seat bones are not too strained on my saddle ISM PL 1.1 in my beloved cycling shorts Skinfit tri shorts and Assos half shorts.
As my lucky item I absolutely have to bring my little scuffed white BEAR with me, who accompanied me on the NorthCape4000 and Three Peaks Bike Races, among others.

Exposure front and rear light with the addition of a head torch up front and an extra rear light. 2x power banks to keep everything charged which I‚Äôll re charge when stopped. Garmin 530 to track and map my route with additional power bank. Warm clothes for downtime and a waterproof jacket for when the weather turns. I‚Äôll keep my sleep setup in my bar bag which consists of bivvy, sleeping bag and air mattress.

Age
: 30
Location

Wheels are DT Swiss GR531 650b kindly hand built by a club mate Richard Gate who is currently out riding TCRNo8 as part of the first ever father-son pair (251a/b). Tyres are Terravail Rutlands (durable casing) set up tubeless. Spares mounted on down tube.

: Ortlieb front bar bag: Women's Mountain Equipment Helium 400 sleeping bag, Black Diamond Spotlight hooped bivvy (for escaping the midgees), Sea to Summit Ultralight mat and pillow.
Topeak top tube bag: 10,000 mAh battery pack, iPod nano, Nokia 105, tracker and Sea to Summit Nano daypack.
Apidura and Alpkit food stash bags: All the snacks
Apidura full frame bag: 1.5L water bladder, even more spares, chain wax, spare sealant and first aid kit (including lots of caffeine tablets), wash kit, chamois cream, suncream, spork, midge net, arm warmers, Gore Shakedry jacket and sealskinz hood.
Ortlieb saddle bag: Rapha Core bib shorts, long sleeve jersey, warm base layer, leg warmers and Proviz high viz bib for night riding and Alpkit towel. Inov-8 merino top, running shorts and Haglofs LIM Essens down jacket for sleeping and Theraband/ball for some maintenance. Another 20,000 mAh battery for charging. Spare Inov-8 water bladder for Stage 4.

Age
: 37
Location

Tyres are Panaracer Gravel Kings SK being ran tubeless with a foam insert for rock protection topped off with Peaty's X Chris King valves and mini tools. Groupset is SRAM Force 1x. 38t front and 11-42t rear. Pedals are Nukeproof dual sided spds with a large flat surface. Bars are 440mm flared with prime double tape. Also attached are a small set of tri bars. Finally the saddle is a Specialized Power saddle, 155mm wide.
Key items of kit
: Front bag is the Restrap Race 7L bar bag. 2x food pods off my stem. A large Zefel top tube bag for all my charging admin. Beneath that is my half frame bag again by Restrap. Rear we have a Tailfin AeroPack with alloy frame. Attached are 2x anything cages with Restrap straps for security. 3x bottle cages for water plus a tool pod underneath the frame. Navigation will be the Wahoo ELMNT BOLT and spare for back up. Lights are Exposure Trace on the rear and Nestling front tried and tested. Grayl filter will be set on the anything cage with my trusty Jetboil the other side. I will have a small one man tent and usual change of clothes. A length of Great Britain in August demands riders come prepared for all eventualities. Have a browse of what each intrepid rider thinks they'll need for this ride.

Age
: 52
Location
: Coventry
Bike
: On one big dog
Key items of kit
: Coffee
George Lees
Name

Age
: 36
Location
: Chapel En Le Frith
Bike
: Santa Cruz Chameleon. Fox 34 shocks, hand built wheels, Shimano XTR/Box components with 9 speed friction franken gears. Maxxis tyres.
Key items of kit
: Bags are a mix of Restrap, Revelate, Witslingers and Alpkit. 2 litre water bladder in the frame bag and water filter for sipping pond water. Midgey proof headnet, dodgy ali express tent and a hipflask full of Whiskey.
Justin Dean
Name
: Justin Dean
Age
: 54
Cap number
: Deano
Location
: Whitstable, England
Bike
: Vitus Rapide, XT groupset 1x12 - 30T Front 10x51 cassette, Rockshox Ultimate 100 mm fork, trying the Cane Creek+ seat post 35mm travel, Selle Italia Dynamic saddle, Stooge Moto bar with with Sqlab bar inners and Profile Design tri bars. Tyres are Vittoria Barzo front and Mezcal rear 29x2.25, Ergon grips and Nukeproof flat pedals!!!!!
Key items of kit
: Bags are a mix. Rear is a Tailfin AeroPack which will be carrying my wet weather gear including Endura MT500 trousers, GoreTex Shakedry and Rab jackets. Tent is a Terra Nova Southern cross 1, Therm-a-Rest Xtherm medium wide pad, pillow is Alpkit and a Rab silk liner. also an extra water bottle holder.
Frame bag is Oveja Negra which will carry my extra cycling clothes; arm & leg warmers, neck buff, couple of pairs of gloves and waterproof sock. Apidura top tube bag will have my electrics 20000mAh and 10000mAh battery packs, plugs and charging cables. I will be using a Garmin Edge 1030+ for navigation with my iPhone on the quad lock as backup. My lights are Exposure Race and Exposure Joystick. 2 stem bags will carry my water.
Lastly my Salsa EXP Cradle and bag for all my extra clothing, sleeping bag and Arcteryx Atom LT hoodie for the night riding. Clip on Salsa front bag for food and wash kit. I plan on couple of nights camping then a night in hotel for charging all gear back up including myself...

Key items of kit

Bikes of Three Peaks Bike Race 2022
5 July, 2022
A free-route race that summits three of Europe's most formidable mountains and all those in between before featuring Mt Ventoux as the gateway to the final parcours and finish in Nice, France. This is certainly a race for the grimpeurs.
Riders have made their own decisions on the fine balance between being equipped for the unpredictable Austrian, Italian, Swiss and French Alps whilst also keeping weight down.
Have a scroll to see each rider's chosen whip and the accompanying kit they've chosen.
Stephan Bechert
Name
: Stephan Bechert
Age
: 47
Cap number
: 227
Location
: Bavaria, Germany
Bike
: S-Works Aethos, Shimano DuraAce 9200 34/50 11-34. Stages Powermeter, Bikeahead Biturbo, Hambini BB, Alpinist Post and Cockpit, Carbonworks bottle cage,  Elite 950ml water bottle, Tailfin AeroPack, Custom Foodpouch, Mirror saddle. Continental GP5000 31mm TR, Meti SPD XTR, Wahoo Elemnt 2 and Black Reflective Tape. The bike is 6kg unloaded and 10kg loaded.
Key items of kit
: Lupine SL AF7 + 2x50WH + 25W, Therm-a-Rest Quilt and Uberlight. Rapha RCC merino baselayers and down jacket in Dyneema bags. POC Ventral Lite helmet and stripped down Di2 cable.

main Headlight Busch M√ºller IQ-X Senso Plus LED (on dynamo), 2nd headlight (USB) + headlamp. Axa Slim Steady LED Backlight 50mm (on dynamo), 2nd Backlight (USB) and Garmin Edge 1030 plus.

Navigation: Wahoo Roam. Charging: 20.000 mAh Powerbank. Food: Everything. I'm using a third big bidon as a container for a maltro-sugarmix so I can add it to my bidons. Key items: Two smiling bidons for the mood!

Bike
: This is a T-Lab X3, a custom-made titanium frame made by a great team in Montreal with Boyd Jocassee gravel wheels and Rene Herse Bon Jon Pass in 35mm. There is a SON 28 dynamo hub in front, powering Sinewave Cycles Beacon and Supernova E3 Taillight. Groupset is Sram Force AXS (Rival AXS for the 160mm crank) in 10-36 & 33-46 in front. The frame and food pouch bags are from Copra Bikepacking and are custom-made for the bike in Paris. Saddle and top tube bags are from Apidura.
This is a lighter setup than what I am used to, but the idea is to suffer the least as possible in the climbs and be able to not lose time re-packing.
Key items of kit
: The packable backpack! A great way to stuff food when needed and can be put away easily. And a dry bag to keep my camera safe from any storms.

Manuel Schmid
Name
: Manuel Schmid
Age
: 42
Cap number
: 114
Location
: Oetwil am See, Switzerland
Bike

Key items of kit
: Custom Frame Bag from Rogue Panda and seat Pack from Revelate Designs. Second headlight is a Garmin Varia with helmet mount, backlight from BBB. For sleeping I use a Borah Gear Cuben Bivy, the Sea to Summit Spark Sp0 sleeping Bag and the Sea to Summit Ether light sleeping Mat. If the weather is bad, I prefer to stay in a Hotel üòä. On the bike I wear socks from Compressport, base layer from X-Bionic, shorts from Zoot, merino jersey from Castelli, Lake Shoes, MET Trenta helmet and sunglasses from Julbo. If it is cold I have a vest from Odlo, merino arm and leg warmer from Rapha and a Patagonia Micro Puff Jacket. If it is wet I have a Gore jacket and Endura pants.
Martin Bloch
Name
: Martin Bloch
Age
: 28
Cap number
: 177
Location
: Berlin, Germany
Bike
: My road bike is a handmade, custom built steel frame from Cycles Manivelle (in Strasbourg). It is equipped with a Shimano Ultegra 50/34 - 11-34 to try to climb those Three (and more) Peaks without hurting my knees too much.
I'll ride on Hunt Superdura dynamo wheels that'll power my front and rear lights; this is one less thing to care about during the race. The front light is a Busch und M√ºller IQX, and is powerful enough to ride through the night. The wheels are mounted with 28 mm Hutchinson tires (with tubes).
Key items of kit
: The top tube bag is from Apidura and is fairly common in those types of events I think, so I won't go into details. It'll contain small objects like sunscreen, my credit card or the powerbank.
The frame bag is from Helmut Equipments which is, contrary to what you would think when reading the name, located in the French Alps. I'll store the sleeping gear and the "bathroom" stuff in there.
I'll also use as aerobar bag in which I'll keep the stuff I want to have easy access to when I'm on the bike, such as the wind jacket or the leg warmers. I might also use the upper side of that bag to store snacks!
Last but not least, I'll use a custom built rear rack (which was also built by Cycles Manivelle!). It will carry a 7L dry bag with all the stuff I'll use less often like the down jacket or maybe some spare bib shorts. The rack weighs almost nothing and will prevent the bag from swinging during the climbs.
I'll also carry 2 bottles and might use the 3rd one underneath the frame to store some multitool/spare tube kind of thing.

Key items of kit
: Restrap Look packs.

Bikes of Pan Celtic Race 2022
5 July, 2022
A 2,530km race starting and ending in Wales with a lap of Ireland takes in some of the most unpredictable weather regions of the UK. No edition of the Pan Celtic Race has ever been spared bad weather; the biblical rain at the start in Cornwall in 2021 and the storms in Scotland in 2019 have gone down in PCR Clan legend.
Photo: Rupert Hartley

: Alpkit Koala bike bags x 2, plus stem cells. Pipedream 400 sleeping bag, Cloudbase sleep matt, Hunka bivvy and Rig 3.5 tarp. MytiMug, Koro stove, Flare solar panel. Lights are Exposure Trace, Blaze & Toro. Pluto the Adventure Dawg.

Bikes of Transpyrenees
24 June, 2022
Take a look at rider's chosen bikes and equipment lists for this year's Transpyrenees: a 1,080km road route from Llan√ß√† on the east coast of Spain to San Sebastian on the west coast with 25,000m of elevation and ticking off 33 Pyrenean cols. Certainly a race for the grimpeurs!
Follow along as the race unfolds at
our commentary
.

Key items of kit
: Mix of older Revelate Designs Pika rear bag, Restrap bags and a customized Aeroe front harness. Alpkit / Sea to Summit sleeping kit.
Key for me is the Lester as a perfect fitting tool / companion for long rides. Additionally my kit-list consists mostly older stuff that has proven reliable and dependable over the last 5 years of touring and racing. : 2019 Kona Libre DL, that I got as a Kona Ambassador during my first year in Germany. Bags are a mix of Dom, Gramm, Ortlieb, Outer Shell (not pictured but will be on the bike), Porcelain Rocket, and Salsa. Most of them have been with me on many trips, but the handlebar bag will be making its maiden voyage on TBP. The bike is stock, except for a Brooks saddle, a dyno hub with light, and wide, flared Salsa bars, equipped with Redshift grips. Unfortunately the gearing is stock, so I'll probably be walking a few sections of the route.
Key items of kit
: I'm currently planning on bringing a tent, because I don't have a bivy bag, and my sleep setup is a summer-weight quilt plus mattress. Without a tent I'd be sharing my quilt with every insect in Hesse. I'm hoping to leave my rain fly at the campsite. We'll see what the weather forecast says. I finally treated myself to an inflatable pillow for this trip. Navigation is an older Wahoo Bolt, pulling power from the dyno hub, which will also keep my phone charged and give me the option to listen to audiobooks when I'm somewhere off-route, wondering why my GPS signal is drifting.

The dynamo is connected to a KLite light and charger. Handlebars are 46cm Ritchey Beacon with super comfortable Wolf Tooth bar tape. What else? Redshift ShockStop suspension stem, Shimano XT pedals, Specialized Power saddle, Reverse Fillmore valves, Orange Seal sealant, King Cage Iris bottle cages, SwissStop brake pads,... I'm a professional bike mechanic, so gear nerding is definitely part of the deal.
Key items of kit
: Bags are a mix of Apidura framebags (that long top tube bag is brilliant), Revelate Designs feedbags (have tried others, these are just the best in my opinion) and a Ortlieb saddlebag (been using the bigger version for years, trying out the smaller one now). No backpack for me. I prefer a tent over a bivy, so I'll be bringing my Nordisk Lofoten tent strapped to the rather unique load bearing Mason ISO front fender. Sleeping in a Cumulus bag on a Therm-a-Rest pad. Been navigating with Garmin devices for years and probably won't be changing that anytime soon. Key items of kit

Bike
: After a couple of years riding a 'real' gravel bike, I felt like I wanted something 'a bit bigger'. So I ended up with a Salsa Cutthroat (stock Apex setup - the cheapest built), a drop-bar 29er. I was lucky to find one in stock in my size, and bought it immediately after a test ride (the pandemic was already upon us, but the worldwide bike/parts shortage hadn't yet started). I bought it with the idea of upgrading it over the years, but I ended up transforming it sooner rather than later. As I'm also a bike mechanic, I really enjoy doing all of this stuff! Quite quickly, I built a new wheelset based on DT Swiss parts (difficult to source parts 1,5 years ago), which really transformed the bike! The gearing also needed a bit of care. I have been running an 11-speed 11-46 cassette (used to have sunrace, now Shimano XT) with a 34T chainring in the front for a while now. I had a bit of a love/hate relationship with the stock TRP Spyre cable-actuated disc brakes, so replaced them with SRAM Force hydraulic brakes and levers a couple of months ago. The handlebars were swapped for the oh-so popular Ritchey WCS Venturemax (46cm) and the bartape these days is from Cannondale (but it's been lizard skins, wolftooth,...). The headset, seatpost, derailleur (not the jockey wheels!) and cranks are about the only original parts still on the bike. I recently replaced the original Teravail Sparwoods with a fresh pair, the original rear tyre had almost completely transformed into a slick.....

Tyres are 40mm Continental Terra Speed (tubeless), pushed by a SRAM AXS transmission on a humble 36T chainring matched with a 11-52T cassette.

Location

: J Guillem Tomir Ti Hardtail

Name

Age
: 62
Location

3 BAGS FULL.
Apidura 7L Racing saddle pack. Apidura 7.5L Expedition Full Frame Bag. Modified Revelate Egress front bag. MSR Cooker. Java Drip Coffee filter. Fresh Ground Home Roasted RiDe Coffee. Bivvie or tent, depends on forecast...

: 45
Location

Rock Shox SID Ultimate 100mm forks.

: Bryce Lorcet
Age
: 48
Location
: Kapiti Coast

Name
: Karl Arndt
Age
: 41
Location

Camel bak 18 litre day bag for the bike carry sections and when I have a large load of food/water on board. A lot of spares and first aid kit.  Jet boil cooker for dehy in the downtube bag (not shown in pic but I'll be picking it up at Boyle resupply). Exposure Joystick for back-up helmet-mounted main lighting.

Location

: 41
Location

Rockshox SID WC fork with 100mm travel. Vittoria Mezcal‚Äôs to roll on. Fabric Aircell saddle, because I like my backend‚Ä¶ lol.

Team #nobackpack

Mark Watson
Name
: Mark Watson
Age
: 50
Location
: Lyttelton, New Zealand
Bike

Fox 34 Step Cast fork (120mm). Sram XO & GX drivetrain with 10-50 cassette and 28t Wolf Tooth CAMO chainring. Shimano Deore hydraulic brakes (2 & 4 piston). Watson Revelation Ti handlebar with 32 degree sweep and a couple of ancient Onza bar ends mounted as mini-aeros. Ergon GS1 grips. Selle Anatomica X2 saddle atop a Thomson Masterpiece seatpost with quick release for the steep and technical downhills. Essentially the same set up I had in 2021 except I have switched to 170mm cranks to alleviate Achilles tendon problems.
Key items of kit
: Revelate Designs bags throughout: Pronghorn front harness, 2 Mountain Feed Bags, Magtank 2000, framebag and 8L Terrapin. Extra water, food and essentials inside an Osprey Talon 9L backpack, which also supports the bike on the long carries. Lighting with Fenix UC35 v2 torch (on handlebar) and a Led Lenser MH10 headtorch (mounted on helmet).
Sleeping: OR Helium bivvy bag with Big Agnes Fussell UL quilt and a cheap cut down Z-rest style mat.
Cati Pearson
Name
: Cati Pearson
Age
: 31
Location
: Rotorua
Bike
: 2021 Devinci Kobain kept running smooth and fitted with a replacement rim by Planet Bike. Running a 130mm Rockshox 35 coil fork, Vitoria Mezcal 2.35 tyres, Shimano Deore gearing, Neutron Componentry integrated tool, Shimano clips because #clippedalswinmedals, Bark & Ride sports mudguard and "Beast on a bike" sticker from the nephew.
Key items of kit
: All clothing from the legends at Ground Effect, Cranston mix of bags from friends, AliExpress and Kmart, Macpac cocoon bivvy bag & Aegismax sleeping bag. Camelbak backpack for water and first aid, Ledlenser MH10 headlamp on helmet paired with small bar light.

Age
: 50
Cap number
: HB
Location
: Lyttelton, New Zealand
Bike
: Otso Voytek 27.5+ with 2.6 Maxxis Ardent Race on Hope & DT Swiss alloy wheels. Fox 34 Step Cast fork (120mm). Sram GX drivetrain with 10-50 cassette and 28t Wolf Tooth CAMO chainring. Shimano Deore hydraulic brakes (2 & 4 piston). Watson Revelation Ti handlebar with 32 degree sweep and mini-aeros. Selle Anatomica X2 saddle and Fox Transfer seat dropper.
Key items of kit
: Revelate Designs bags: Pronghorn front harness, Mountain Feed Bags, Magtank 2000, Otso custom framebag and seat dropper compatible Vole (7L). Extra water, food and essentials inside an Osprey Tempest 18L backpack, to off-load the bike on the HAB and long carries. Lighting with Fenix UC35 v2 torch (handlebar) and a Led Lenser MH10 headtorch (helmet). Sleeping: OR Helium bivvy bag with customised quilt and a barely adequate piece of Z-rest style mat (who has time to sleep anyway?)
Nina Stupples
Name
: Nina Stupples
Age
: 55
Location
: Westport, NZ
Bike
: Specialized Epic 29er aka "Erica"
Key items of kit
: Memory foam butt-saving seat cover,  fly and bivy, REI inflatable mat, sadly no room for a stove. Revelate bags and an Apidura mini frame bag. 30 litre backpack waiting for me at Boyle river for the hike-a-bike. Flat pedals and Salewa Firetail tramping shoes.
Mike Martin

: Mike Martin
Age
: 37
Location
: Hamilton
Bike
: GT Pantera with Hope Fortus wheels and 120mm travel on the front. Maxxis Icons 2.25". Shimano XT 11-speed drivetrain running oval 32T x 46/11. Jones loop bar. Spank spoon pedals
Key items of kit
: Ground effect bibs and a Rapha top (cheers to my mate Shaun). Adidas/Fiveten trailcross shoes. Bags are Blackburn seat, frame and 2x feedbags, apidura racing top tube and revelate front roll strapped direct to the Jones bars.
Garmin Edge for navigation with phone for back up. Gloworm lights. Kathmandu sleeping bag and mat with Outdoor Research bivvy. Merino thermals, jumper and a Macpac puffer for when it gets cold. Kathmandu rain gear top and bottom.
Andie Lowry
Name
: Andie Lowry
Age
: 38
Location
: Kingston
Bike
: Kona HEI HEI DL
Key items of kit
: Bum bag
Scott Ardern

: SA

: Nelson

: Specialized Epic HT

: Revelate bags, SON Dynamo and K-Lite lights Fenix helmet backup light, Sea To Summit Alto Tent, Big Agnes sleeping bag, Jones Carbon bars, Maxxis Ikon 29 x 2.35 tyres.

Bikes of GranGuanche Audax Trail
11 January, 2022
GranGuanche Audax Trail
was a self supported route across the Canary Islands.
The route was mainly double tracks, but includes a few rocky single tracks, sandy sections, short hike-a-bikes, and the minimal amount of tarmac to connect everything. For hardtail mountain bikes or monstercross gravel bikes with low gearing and min 2.1‚Ä≥ wide tires.

Location:

This time, in order to test a more racy machine on a ultracycling race, I will ride the 2VS with my Focus Izalco Max Disc. It will be equipped with Shimano Dura-Ace 50/34-11/30 (usually 52/36-11/28). The wheels are Duke Baccara SLS2 42 (DT Swiss hubs) mounted with GP5000TL 28mm.
Your key items of kit:
A complete bikepack kit from Miss Grape and Garmin Edge 1030 Plus for navigation.
Leighn Csontos Chambers
Age:
35
Location:
Oban, Scotland
Cap number:
17
Your bike:
Canyon Ultimate SL Shimano Ultegra groupset with Absolute Black 2 x Oval rings 46/30. and 11-34 cassette with GRX 810 rear derailleur. Zipp Service Course drop bars. Hunt Wheels with Son 28 dynamo
Your key items of kit:
NOT a frame bag (The inside of my legs will thank me).  Summit 2 Sea lightweight sleeping bag and Rab lightweight bivvy (I‚Äôll be too shagged to care where I‚Äôm sleeping and what I‚Äôm even sleeping in). Restrap saddle bag and Apidura bar bag. Universal Colours Jersey when its hot (it‚Äôs like wearing the caressing hands of a 1980s fairy liquid ad) Rapha merino top for when it‚Äôs cold. Rapha Cargo Bibs to protect the jewels. Location:

Borse ARCH custom,  Anteriore da 2L,  2 per il cibo da 1L,  borsa da sella 12L , navigazione Garmin Edge 1030+. Sleep bivybag by Ferrino and Abbigliamento Ph.
Marianne Thissen-Smits

54
Location:
Egmond aan den Hoef, Netherlands
Cap number:
86

Specialized Amira S-Works 2015 with my son‚Äôs DT Swiss PR 1600 wheels  and 28mm continental GP5000s. Gearing 50-34 and 11-34.
Your key items of kit:
Tailfin Aeropack (for extra clothing and spares ), an Apidura top tube bag (for electronics and food)  and two Apidura pouches (for food). I‚Äôll be wearing different layers which can be changed according to weather conditions. If it gets really cold I have a Patagonia Nano Puff jacket. My friend lent me her Lupine lighting set for the night. I also have an Exposure Lights Reakt rear light and extra Lezyne lights as backup. I‚Äôll be carrying two Xstorm Fuel powerbanks plus a Lupine power bank. A Wahoo ROAM will be used to navigate.
Thomas Boury
Age:
29
Location:
Lyon, France
Cap number:
104
Your bike:
Ritchey Logic Heritage 2018 (Steel Frame) limited edition: 17/100 (I'm born on 17th Oct!), Zipp 30 wheelset, 28m Continental 4 season tyres, Sram Red 48/34 ‚Äì 11/30, Brooks C13 saddle, Shimano SPD pedals
Your key items of kit:
Restrap Large frame bag (food, spare tools, cables) It allow me to have a 750ml bidon (I‚Äôm riding a small frame), Apidura food pouch and frame bag (food), Topo Design handlebar bag (clothes): arms warmers, eg warmers, down jacket, rain jacket, high visibility gilet, gloves and a buff. Age:
45
Location:
Le Mans, Paris
Cap number:
22
Your bike:
My bike is a FAIRLIGHT Secan 2 : for 7 years, inspired by the French rider Patrick Miette (TCR & SRMN veteran), I've been riding a black GENESIS Croix de Fer. After 50000km, I wanted to experiment something new. I was however embarrassed as my valiant and loyal "CdF" led me twice till Meteora through Europe, climbed some volcanoes in Italy, explored All Points North in England. I couldn't just turn the page, so I chose his "brother", also designed by Dom Thomas since he quit Genesis to found Fairlight Cycles.I was embarrassed not to choose a French brand but Fairlight seduced me. 36
Location:
Geneva, Switzerland

69B

Garmin Edge 830, eTrex 30 for navigation and warm clothes for long nights.

Location:

Age:
33
Location:
Berlin, Germany
Cap number:
24

Your key items of kit:

Charging will rely on 30 000 mAh Powerbanks. Navigation: Wahoo Elemnt Roam. I hope to sleep in Hotels but as a safe option I also carry a light sleepsystem consisting of a Cumulus Ultralight Bivi, Decathlon inflatable pillow, Rescue blanket and probably a sea of summit SP0 sleeping bag as I expect the temperatures to be quite chilly at night. I will wear a summer kit with additional warmers, vest and most importanly: My Patagonia down jacket I bought during this year's Three Peaks Bike Race, which kept me cosy even in roughest conditions.
Niklas Hanses
Age:
26
Location:
D√ºsseldorf, Germany
Cap number:
97
Your bike:

Your key items of kit:

In this I carry all the stuff I need to fix the bike, like multitool, derailleur hanger, aerothan innertubes, chainlinks and CO2 cartridges. In case of a mechenical I just have to flip the bike around, have everything I need right there so I am hopefully soon again ready to go. Other than that: Garmin Edge 530 for navigation, Lupine lights for the night with one spare battery which also serves as a powerbank. My bags are a mix between Apidura, Ortlieb and Topeak. Inside you find sleeping and bivvy bag, sleeping pad, rain gear, downjacket, gloves, windbraker emergency blanket etc... The top tube bag is mainly for food to access while riding.
Alexander Ali Kopp
Age:
34
Location:
Innsbruck, Austria
Cap number:
48
Your bike:
I will riding a Santa Cruz Stigmata 2020 custom build, with Shimano/ Rotor mix. My wheels are from Beast Components with the Conti 5000 with 32mm.

Everything I carry will be in my Apidura Kit. My light-Setup is from lupine. I tried to make my setup as lightly as possible. My clothes are in the saddlebag. Food and the rest is in the frame bag.

Age:
26
Location:
Berlin, Germany
Cap number:
31
Your bike:
I‚Äôm riding a Specialized Allez with 28mm tyres. This bike has seen the world, covering together more than 40.000km all over Europe. Attached you‚Äôll find an Ornot handlebar bag, a small Restrap frame bag, and the super lightweight Apidura saddlepack from their race edition.
Your key items of kit:
The bike! Jokes aside, I‚Äôm optimising for weight & warmth, without bringing the usual bivy set up. This time I will ride with dynamo lights, which should prove to be useful on such short days. The Wahoo Bolt will keep me on the right track. When not riding or hike-a-biking, I‚Äôll be wearing my trusted Toms shoes. I‚Äôll also bring my pocket camera: cannot let myself travel to such beautiful places without capturing some nice photos along the way.

53
Location:
Maastricht, Netherlands
Cap number:
90a/90b

3T exploro RACE Sram Rival AXS, Grey/Orange 2021, we made some custom components, we changed the gering into¬†30/43 in combination with 10/44. Small modification around farr¬†gravel¬†handlebar¬†carbon. We added also 3T Discus carbon700c fitted with 35 mm tubules tyres.
Your key items of kit:
We added two stickers on the bike. #Solosalita. Corporate Social Responsibility by MIkeBikes (www.mikebikes.my). We sleep in B&B and Hotels. Our mission is to be on time for the finisher's party.

For the crankset, I changed the round chainring to Osymetric 50/34 teeth. These oval chainrings help me on the uphills. The chain is lubricated by AbsoluteBlack Graphen Lube. title: Bikes of Great British Divide 2021
body:
DotWatcher.cc
Event Commentary
Results
Event Calendar
Features
About Us
Bikes of Great British Divide 2021
24 July, 2021
Warning: this feature contains offensive wallpaper which some readers may find distressing.
Kate Sullivan
Age:
49
Location:
Doncaster, England
Your bike:
My much loved Bombtrack Hook EXT, I hope we are still friends in a few weeks. Running 650b wheels with 2.2" Maxxis IKONs, tubeless. Ritchie WCS Venturemax bars. 11 speed 1x SRAM Rival set up, replaced the stock 40T Chainring with a 30T, for the sake of my knees! Lights: Exposure Maxx D to floodlight the way. No dynamo, got some charging bricks so will have to stop to charge these every few days.
Your key items of kit:
Wahoo ELEMNT ROAM and Wahoo ELEMNT BOLT for a back up. Clothing: Rapha Cargo bibs and tech tee, Patagonia Micro Puff Hoody, waterproof socks. Sleep kit: My very old Alpkit Ordos 2 tent, its not the lightest out there but it does pack down small, I can put it up blindfolded, it's roomy and it keeps the midges out (mostly), so it's coming. Therm-a-Rest Hyperion sleeping bag, Therm-a-Rest NeaAir XLite mat. Bags: a mix of Apidura, Alpkit and a homemade frame bag. Many Voile straps and a Decathlon micro rucksack for additional snacks. Spares: 2 x mech hangers and many spare brake pads, let's hope they're enough. I wouldn't be without the DynaPlug tubeless repair tool. Luxuries/other: midge/tick repellant, lip balm, kenesis tape and multivitamins.
Craig Bunyan
Age:
35
Location:
Romsey, Hampshire
Your bike:
Built by The Woods Cyclery in Lyndhurst: XL Ritchey Outback frameset, DT Swiss rims laced to SON28 and hope Pro4 hubs with 27.5x 2.1" durable Teravail Rutland tyres. Shimano R7000 groupset, 30/46t AbsoluteBLACK chainrings, 11/36t cassette and Shimano XT  SPD pedals. Ritchey Classic finishing kit, Sinewave Beacon front light, Supernova E3 rear light, Specialized Power saddle. Wolftooth bar tape and ESI grips on the drops
Your key items of kit:
Alpkit Soloist tent, Alpkit Pipedream 400 sleeping bag, Exped Synmat HL sleeping pad. Ortleib saddle and frame pack, Restrap handlebar bag. Alpkit top tube bags and Wizardworks snack bags. 2x wahoo bolt GPS units charged by 2x 10,000 mAh powerbanks. D15 Clothing: Fizik Terra X5 shoes, MET Trenta helmet. 90% clothing from DHB because it just works: long and sleeveless merino base layers, arm and leg warmers and merino socks.
Stevan Brown
Age:
43
Location:
Crawley, West Sussex
Your bike:
Lynskey MT29. RideFarr Chromo forks. On One Geoff bars. Stans Arch 29‚Äù wheels with Shwalbe Racing Ray/Ralph tyres, both 2.25‚Äù. SRAM Eagle NX/GX mechanical gearing, with a 32t chainring and 11-50 cassette. Sram Level TL brakes.
Your key items of kit:
Saddle pack and custom frame bag from Alpkit. Topeak Fuel Tank. Restrap handlebar bag. Two stem bags from amazon. Two 1 litre bottles on the forks. My riding and weather gear is mainly Decathlon and DHB stuff. I‚Äôm taking two sets of riding gear to alternate when required. Naturehike down bag, inflatable mat and Cloud up 2 tent. Lezyne 1600xxl front light with two rear lights. I‚Äôm not running a dynamo. I have a small 10,000 mah power bank in the top tube bag for my Wahoo Element Bolt and a larger power bank to top up phone and lights when camped. I intend to find some accommodation every 3-4 days where I‚Äôll recharge everything including myself!
Josh Ibbett
Age:
33
Location:
St Neots, England
Your bike:
Mason InSearchOf, custom Hunt wheels, WTB Nano 2.1 tyres, Shimano GRX Di2 groupset. RockShox SID fork and Miss Grape bags
Your key items of kit:
Pack list is pretty similar to my list for GBDURO last year‚Ä¶ minus cooking appliances and a week's worth of food. I‚Äôve included a slightly warmer long sleeve jersey and 3/4 length rain shorts this year, just in case‚Ä¶
Sam Davidson
Age:
30
Location:
Bristol, UK
Your bike:
Trek Procaliber 9.5 with Tailfin Aeropack & front drybag. All stock parts except ergon grips & half flat spd pedals for the inevitable on/off hike a bike! Looking forward to the 50T cassette sprocket for everywhere north of the Severn Bridge
Your key items of kit:
In terms of kit for 2 weeks of unknown weather, I'm convinced merino & minimal is the way forward! An UL survival bivi teamed with a lightweight tent stored on the handlebars is a sleeping setup that I think should cater for a quick power nap at midnight on a lumpy Welsh hillside, or a full relaxing 10hr camp by a Scottish loch to regain some sanity. Lighting is dual Exposure (is there any other way?). And navigation is a Garmin etrex with an Edge 800 backup. A couple of quick charge batteries & other gubbins stored in a Restrap top tube bag will support these as I move too slow off road for my dynamo! The cavernous Tailfin takes most kit, but my Salomon running vest is a welcome addition as it eats gear & food, meaning a bit less on the bike. This also gives the option for a water bladder freeing up a bidon cage for a small thermos. 500ml of strong coffee + 3 sugars = All the late night riding power!!
Jon Kelley
Age:
35
Location:
Farnham, Surrey, UK
Your bike:
Bike is called "Ol' Shonky". She's a no brand Chinese frame that I've built up at home as follows: carbon Chinese frame, 29er, carbon rigid fork, WTB i29 rims laced onto a Koozer XM490 rear hub and an SP Dynamo PD-8X non-boost 15mm front Dynamo hub, using Sapim Race spokes. I built the wheels. XT mechanical drivetrain with 11-42 cassette. Blackspire snaggletooth 30t chainring. SLX brakes, Gorilla metallic pads. Niner carbon seatpost, Selle Italia titanium saddle. 600mm flat bars, 100mm stem, negative rise and slammed. DMR V12 flat pedals, 2x elite flyweight bottle cages, Busch & Muller IQ2 Luxos U front light and USB charger. Front tyre is Schwalbe Rocket Ron 2.2" and rear is Maxxis Ardent Race 2.2". Both setup tubeless.
Your key items of kit:
Alpkit Hunka bivvy, Berghaus Intrepid 700 Sleeping Bag, Gore Oxygen jacket. These three items have been carefully packed by aggressively ramming them into my Apidura seatpack (which has a rear light attached to it)
I have some other not very interesting stuff coming with me too: ibuprofen and paracetemol, hayfever tablets and nasal spray, insect repellent, backup USB front light, small battery pack (3000mAh single 18650 cell), Garmin Edge 800 with Nukeproof topcap mount, USB cables for phone (S10e) and Garmin, small decanted bottle of Finish Line Wet lube, small decanted bottle of tubeless spaff Stans. 1x 29er inner tube and tubeless repair kit. Topeak Mountain Morph pump. Crank brothers multi-tool with chain breaker. 2 spokes (1 each of the sizes used in the wheel build). Needle and thread for tyre repair. Camelbak Rogue backpack with water bladder. Zip ties. Gorilla tape. 1x 500ml and 1 x 750ml flyweight bottles. That's the hardware. I'll be wearing a custom printed t-shirt that I made for the event, baggy shorts with some bibs underneath, DC casual shoes with a waffle pattern sole that should stick to the V12s nicely and some neon orange socks for a bit of additional dynamic visibility for the road section.  I'll start and finish in the same clothes. I pity anyone downwind of me.
Michael Travers
Age:
48
Location:
Canewdon, Essex
Your bike:
I am the owner of Travers Bikes and I make Titanium frames, so I will be naturally riding one of my own designs: the Travers RUSSTi EVO with my own designed carbon fork the Travers XC Prong, SRAM XX1 Eagle AXS with Garbaruk 10-52 cassette, Hope Tech 3 X2 brakes, Zwatt carbon powermeter with Garbaruk 30t chainring, Travers Titanium H2 Handlebars, Travers Titanium H2 seatpost, Travers Titanium stem, Hope Tech Pro 4 rear hub rear SON 28 Boost dynamo hub on Nextie carbon rims and Maxis Icon 27.5 x 2.8 front, 27.5 x 2.6 rear. Ergon GS2 Grips plus Ergon Saddle.
Your key items of kit:
kLite Bikepacker ULTRA MTB dynamo light with kLite USB and kLite Qube dual Rear Light. 7rbags.com custom frame bag, Toppeak MTS bag with Tetrarack M2.
Andy Dodd
Age:
28
Location:
Derby, UK
Your bike:
Sonder Broken Road, SRAM Eagle NX 11-50. 32T. SRAM Guide T brakes. Confucius handlebars. Tailfin Aeropack.
Your key items of kit:
The nature of these events means that every bit of kit is a key item! I'm not in it to win it, so I'm leaned towards the comfort side a bit more than some will have.  Sleeping system comprising Alpkit Elan hooded bivvy, OMM Raid 1.6 & inflatable pillow of course. Clothing anywhere from Shorts and S/S jersey to full wet weather gear revitalised by Grangers. Headnet and midge spray! Electronics consist of 2 x 20000mAh battery packs to keep Wahoo Elemnt Roam, phone, lights & DJI Osmo charged. Nutrition system includes Alpkit Kraku stove, Ti mug, some Firepot meals, with plenty of snacks!
Harry Fletcher
Age:
28
Location:
Nottinghamshire
Your bike:
Salsa El Mariachi, 29x2.3" Mezcal tyres, Chris King and SP Dynamo laced onto DT Swiss 421 rims, XTR groupset, Thompson finishing fit.
Your key items of kit:
kLite front light, a mixture of Alpkit, Revelate Designs and Apidura bags, Sea To Summit sleeping set up and Nordisk Lofoten tent. Clothing is a mix of Patagonia and 7mesh.
Ian Grace
Age:
52
Location:
Horley / Windermere, UK
Your bike:
Planet X Mutsu Titanium frame with Rockshox - 29"  tubeless set up. 2X11 Shimano XT gears and brakes, Son Dynamo hub. Tailfin rear bag. Redshift Sports bars and grips, with Yak bar extensions on a Fred bar. Quad Lock mount for phone. Profile Designs flip up tri bar rests.
Your key items of kit:
Not packed yet, but Rapha Cargo shorts (just brilliant), Teranova Laser photon tent, Tivex ground sheet, Alpkit sleeping mat and OMM 1.6 sleeping bag. MSR stove with Planet X titanium pot. Garmin Edge 810 for Navigation and iPhone / Fenix 6Pro for back up. Sleep kit on bars, Clothes in the Tailfin, Electronics on top tube bag, Snacks in fuel can bag and anything else (toothbrush, suntan lotion, Gurney goo, spares, pump, food etc etc in the frame bag.
Niel Copeland
Age:
46
Location:
Balcombe, West Sussex
Your bike:
Shand Bahookie drop bar, Salt Carbon wheels shod with Barzo front and Mezcal rear tyre, DT Swiss forks, Hope RX brakes and a Di2 mashup of XTR and DuraAce, Rotor inPower cranks. Amazing that Shand turned this around in 6 weeks from conception to first ride with both Salt and Butternut Bikes helping with accelerated parts delivery! I've built this bike up to be the ultimate long distance off-road speed machine!
Your key items of kit:
My trusty Tailfin aero pack is the heart of the luggage system. Sleep kit is an OR Helium bivy, Big Agnes sleeping bag and mat, all wrapped up in an Apidura bar bag. Snacks in the feedbacks and frame bag. Navigation is taken care of with the Garmin Edge 1030 plus and extra cell, should only need to recharge once. Front light is an Exposure Diablo and rear a Cat Eye. Power is a 10k mAh power bank and 3 port USB C charger. Clothing includes an Endura Pro insulated jacket, Gore Shakedry top, Paclite waterproof trousers, and a thermal top and running shorts so I have some off the bike evening wear.
Stu Taylor
Age:
44
Location:
Kirkby Lonsdale, England
Your bike:
Sonder Dial, Hope Wheels and Components, Pirelli Scorpion Tyres, Carbon Jones Bar with Ergon grips, Brooks Saddle with Ultimate USE Vybe seat post, Alpkit bikepacking¬†luggage bags and Tailfin Aeropack.
Your key items of kit:
Saddle and seat post combo to help avoid saddle sores. Sleeping setup Alpkit Soloist tent, Pipe dream sleeping bag, Cloudbase mat and Alpkit riding clothes and layers.  Navigation using Garmin eTrex and iPhone Komoot backup.
I'm trying to keep the bike balanaced and the weight spread evenly across the bike, using a front bag and rear Tailfin Aeropack, but I may add small frame bag after some last minute faffing.
Donnacha Cassidy
Age:
32
Location:
Killarney, Ireland
Your bike:
Specialized Stumpjumper frame, SRAM XO/XX 2x10, Maxxis Aspen 2.2 tubeless, Stans Crest MK3 rims with SON dynamo and kLite light, Garmin eTrex.
Your key items of kit:
Front roll: SOL Bivy, Sea to Summit sleeping bag liner, bug net, pillow and merino wool layers. Seat pack: some clothing and extra room. Frame pack: tools and electronics. I‚Äôll have a Salomon vest for carrying food.
Carolyn Chambers
Age:
35
Location:
Oban, Scotland
Your bike:
Fairlight Secan, Hope components, Rotor power meter and Shimano GRX Di2
Your key items of kit:
Wahoo ELEMNT for nav and Quad Lock for phone which will be my back-up nav. Assos Laalalai shorts as it‚Äôs the only chamois that doesn‚Äôt give me sores! Lightweight Cafe du Cycliste Audax jersey. GORE Shakedry waterproof jacket as it's light and packable. OMM Halo waterproof trousers. Mixture of Apidura and Restrap bags, as I find this combo keeps weight central and provides easy access. Exposure Strada main light, Diabolo and Joystick as backups. 2x 10000 mAh battery packs.
Chris Hinds
Age:
36
Location:
Glasgow, Scotland
Your bike:
2008 ish Gary Fisher Superfly (semi-retired until a few weeks ago), some SRAM Apex borrowed off my CX bike with some flared bars that were kicking about. Old but gold XTR chainset with a custom Rolhoff chainguide.
Your key items of kit:
Planning on using Rapha Cargo bibs with the Brevet jersey for plenty of pocket space. Stem bags and tool roll are custom Coubywan X Albannach bags. Front dry bag is held in place using the super neat DrJon Bagworks strap deck and Albannach Voile straps. Kit wise, after snoring/choking myself awake on Transpyrenees I‚Äôm really excited to have a bit of luxury with my Big Agnes AXL pillow. This is also my first time riding with a Dynamo so I‚Äôm looking forward to seeing how this changes my planning and tactics for this ride without having to plan around charging times.
Jon Large
Age:
53
Location:
Ryedale, England
Your bike:
Shand Bahookie with Rohloff drive, Gates belt, carbon Jones loop bar, 27.5 Hope Fortus 35 rims with 3.0 Rocket Rons, Son 28, Thudbuster LT (not in photo) and Infinity seat. Huge thanks to Saul at Shand for helping with some last minute maintenance.
Your key items of kit:
Revelate Designs (RD) Sweetroll with hammock and CF tarp (MLD Trailstar and Ookworks inner if weather looks bad - there‚Äôs room for the bike in here too!) and PHD half bag and quilt. Jones H-bar pack with electronics. RD Mag Tank for food and Adipura feed bags for Ti mug/Alpkit stove/coffee/food and water bottle. RD Ranger framebag for toolkit, spares, pump, first aid, food and to-hand-clothing. RD Spinelock 16lt for clothing and wash kit. Wearing Assos trail shorts, NZO shorts, Alpkit and Decathlon merino jerseys, and GORE Shakedry jacket and Ground Effect Gore-Tex shorts. Using a Wahoo ELEMNT ROAM for navigation.
Thomas Casey
Age:
30
Location:
Colchester, England
Your bike:
Cotic Solaris max XL . Fox 34 with no volume spacers, Reverb dropper post with Ergon saddle, Mavic wheels with Son Plus Dynamo wired to a kLite charger. 2.35" Maxxis Ikon up front and a 2.2 "Pirelli Scorpion on the rear
Your key items of kit:
Bags are a combination orfRestrap (new custom frame bag) and Topeak, I will also be using a very light Evoc hydration backpack.  I have an Exposure light so I can make use of the South Downs descents on the first night :) . My luxury item is my 4 poster Big Agnes sleeping bag and pad, I plan to use 0 hotels. I also have a supper comfy pair of trusty Mavid XA shoes
Alun Lewis
Age:
43
Location:
Bournemouth, England
Your bike:
It's a steel Ribble CGR with Wild Cat frame and seat packs, and Alpkit top tube bag with 2 large stem bags for food and electrics.  I have the kLight MTB light and Son Deluxe Dynamo hub. The frame is finished with orange Hope cranks and rotors with Hunt Superdura wheelset.
Your key items of kit:
Apart from the 2 bottles on the frame in taking a 1.5l bum bag for water. I'm taking a Terra Nova tent, Big Agnes quilt and Therm-a-Rest. A merino top, leggings and a change of cycling kit. Also taking a small stove. Hope it's enough üôè
Richard Beaumont
Age:
54
Location:
Sheffield, England
Your bike:
Trek 1120, Bontrager carbon wheels and 3‚Äù tyres.
Your key items of kit:
I'll be navigating with Hammerhead Karoo 2, Alpkit Aeronaut tent with Rab Neutrino 200 sleeping bag. Rapha cargo short cos I like the pockets and a The People's Poncho (keeps everything dry and you don‚Äôt sweat to death).
Sam Phillips
Age:
19
Location:
Lincoln, England
Your bike:
Commencal Meta HT AM. Rockshox 35 Forks with 150mm of travel. WTB Rims with SON28 dynohub connected to a Sinewave Revolution. 29 x 2.2‚Äù Continental Cross Kings. Shimano XT/SLX with 11-50 cassette and 32t chainring. Sram Level brakes. Ritchey seatpost with fi‚Äôzi;k Tiaga saddle. Ride Alpha bars and stem with DMR Brendog Deathgrips.
Your key items of kit:
Alpkit Soloist. Berghaus sleeping bag. Sea to Summit mat. Alpkit Kraku stove with titanium mug. Dehydrated meals. Spare set of merino riding clothes plus waterproofs. Tools and spares. Garmin Edge 1030+ for navigation with Komoot on phone as backup. Moon front and rear lights. 20100mAh battery and dynohub to keep everything charged. All rammed into a mixture of Alpkit, Podsacks, Topeak and homemade bags.
Maurice Guy (everyone calls me Mo)
Age:
29
Location:
Corfe Mullen, Dorset, England
Your bike:
Sonder Camino AL set up on GRX 11 speed. Everything‚Äôs pretty much as it came from sonder, I‚Äôm still running the 11-42 cassette with a 40T chain ring,  the only thing that‚Äôs changed is the front wheel, which I had built for the event around a SON 28 dynamo, the tyres which are continental race kings in 700cx50mm. And I‚Äôve added some aero bars just to give my wrists a break.
Your key items of kit:
My accommodation is an Alpkit Soloist tent, Alpkit Numo Matt, Mountain Equipment Firefly sleeping bag. I‚Äôve got a Rab down jacket, an old but trusty Marmot waterproof coat to keep my warm and dry. an Alpkit Kraku stove, a titanium pot and a couple of dehydrated meals. (I prefer taking some food and a way of cooking it, I think the extra options it gives you make up for weight, it‚Äôs not such as issue if you can‚Äôt find anywhere for dinner or you choose to ride on a bite late or the weather turns and you have to hunker down early). 2 pairs of Sealskins waterproof socks: one knee high and one regular. The knee high ones are great for wading through undergrowth or streams. I‚Äôve got a SON front light and Sinewave usb charger running from the Dynamo. I‚Äôm using a Garmin Edge 530 for navigation with my phone for backup. I‚Äôve got a Dakine waste pack for hydration and snacks. I‚Äôve got two spare tubes, spare mech hanger, spare gear cable, a chain quick link, a couple of spokes and some brake pads.

title: Bikes of Three Peaks Bike Race 2021
body:
DotWatcher.cc
Event Commentary
Results
Event Calendar
Features
About Us
Bikes of Three Peaks Bike Race 2021
9 July, 2021
Jana Kesenheimer
Age:
27
Location:
Innsbruck, Austria
Cap number:
36
Your bike:
Specialized Aethos Pro Ultegra Di2 (a real weight-saver)
Your key items of kit:
In order to make perfect use of the space on my little bike (size 49), I am using a mix of bags from different manufacturers this year. The orlieb bag perfectly fits into my frame. The bottles are mounted on the Woho Saddle Bag Stabilizer.¬†In addition, I do without a handlebar bag, but rely on aero bars this time. The Lupine Neo2 (on the handlebars) accompanies me at night, the Lupine 'Rotlicht' is mounted on the saddlebag. To rest, I will sleep on the Sea to Summit ultralight mat and in a Sea to Summit Traveller TrI sleeping bag.
Joel Karolin
Age:
26
Location:
Switzerland, Biel/Bienne
Cap number:
103
Your bike:
Cube Agree C:62 Race, Shimano Ultegra, Hunt Dynamo Wheel. Exposure Lights lighten the night and offer the mounts needed for my bike. I‚Äôm using a kLite bar switch to couple the dynamo either to the lights or to a Sinewave converter in order to charge my portable lights, smartphone, or wahoo element (navigation). To get me and my bike on the top of the mountains I use the biggest Ultegra cassette (11-34) available.
Your key items of kit:
All the bags are from Apidura. I only use Castelli bibshorts while using Endura tops to keep me warm and comfy, but not too cozy so that I also take advantage of my portable bed, namely a super light sleeping bag with a little air mattress. Well all my parts are not that little since they have to fit me (2 meters in height). In terms of safety I attached all the reflectors required.
Matthieu Lifschitz
Age:
46
Location:
Marseille, France
Cap number:
123
Your bike:
I will start with almost the same setup as on the Two Volcano sprint which gave me full satisfaction during the race. I'm riding my 2019 made to measure Victoire Cycles "Gaby" Handmade with Columbus Steel + Curve carbon fork. I have a Sram force 1 group set (Garbaruk 38 T + 9-46 E-Thirteen). A custom wheel set Mavic all road carbon rims + Son dynamo hub + Mavic MR801 rear hub + Teravail Rampart 700x42 Tubeless (just because "fat tires make me happy").
Your key items of kit:
I have a full Helmut Equipement sport setup where I can have a proper sleeping system with bivy, sleeping bag, pillow and mattress. I usually try to sleep as little as possible in hotels. I love to never cut the race and stay outside, Hotels, except for a "ravito", are only in case of no shelters in very bad weather or in case of illness. I especially love to have several little bags instead of one or two big. More useful, and easy to find something. I'll be wearing a full Caf√© du Cycliste kit, especially with the Audax range which is dedicated for long distance ride and is great for it! Wahoo Roam for navigation and a iPhone 11 Pro as backup, and obviously sound system.
Considering the incredible mountains we are going to cross, I will take a small Ricoh GR3 to get some nice pictures. My ultimate weapon is a range of playlists who mix discoid parts, some Stevie Wonder or Prince masterpieces with a bunch of golden age hip hop and a lot of other catchy curiosities as riding partner.
Simon Schreck
Age:
35
Location:
Berlin, Germany
Cap number:
144
Your bike:
Custom build Bombtrack Audax 2021 with Ultegra 2x11 groupset, custom build DT swiss/Shutter Precission Wheelset, Supernova lightning system.
Your key items of kit:
Apidura Racing series toptube, frame and saddle bag. Handlebar bag from lifeisaride, which was customized to attach to the aerobars. Really happy about this arrangement. Handy, spacious and stable. One set of gear for on the bike. A mix of 7mesh, PEDaLED and DHB. Bad weather cloth in the handlebar bag. sleeping bag, matt, pillow cover in the saddle pack. Frame and toptube bad for small essentials.
Nikolaus Mellauner
Age:
35
Location:
Vienna, Austria
Cap number:
131
Your bike:
Simplon Pavo Granfondo with Shimano Ultegra 8000 (50/34 and 11/34); Alloy DT Swiss wheels and Continental GP5000 (25mm) with tubes; Lupine Neo front light.
Your key items of kit:
Mix of Apidura and Ortlieb bags; Garmin 830 for navigation; light down sleeping bag and inflatable mat for sleeping outside; I will wear my beloved T√∏rm Merino jersey and Gore bib shorts.
Simone Eder
Age:
40
Location:
Basel, Switzerland
Cap number:
18
Your bike:
LOLA//Enigma Etape Custom Titanium with 650b handbuilt DCR wheels, Schwalbe Pro One tires tubeless 28mm, Son deluxe dynamo hub with Sinewave front light and Supernova rearlight, Fizik Luce saddle, Zipp seatpost, Shimano Ultegra groupset.
Your key items of kit:
Wild mix of Apidura Bags, Woho saddelbag stabilizer for bottle mount, Garmin 530 and good old eTrex20, Sea to Summit Flame I sleeping bag, ThermaRest Neoair xlite mat, Bora Gear UL bivi, 7mesh Wk3 bibs, Rapha Pro Team Jersey, Giro Sica Techlace MTB Shoes.
Thomas Ceyrowsky
Age:
38
Location:
D√ºsseldorf, Germany
Cap number:
25
Your bike:
My bike named Argos is a GT Grade AL(uminium) 105 from 2016. 30-46 crank and 11-34 cassette to compensate for a lack of training ;). Tyres are Continental‚Äôs GP 5000 (clinchers) on some custom made wheels (RR521). In the front wheel there is a SON 28 dynamo hub, powering the B&M IQ-X front, the SON backlight and the Sinewave Revolution charger.
Your key items of kit:

Frame Packs from Apidura and seat Pack from Revelate Designs. Supernova Lights. For Navigation i use a Wahoo Elemnt. On the Bike i wear Socks and Shirt from Compressport, base layer from X-Bionic, Shorts from Zoot, Lake Shoes, MET Trenta helmet and Sunglasses from Julbo.
